    Bondsman or bail bondsman means any person who shall, in any court having criminal jurisdiction or in any criminal action or proceeding within the city, including the municipal court, for another deposit cash, bonds or securities or execute as surety any bond or recognizance and who shall receive any compensation therefore. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-52. - License required. 
    No person shall write or furnish bail bonds for compensation or engage in the bail bond business within the city without first securing a license from the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-53. - Issuance of license; financial statement; surety. 
    Under this article, the city clerk shall issue a license to an applicant, in accordance with the amount specified in section 18-22, upon the presentation of a financial statement of such applicant, the correctness of which the applicant has subscribed and sworn to before a notary public. The statement shall bear the written approval of at least four members of the board of commissioners signifying their approval of the applicant to engage in the bail bond business, together with a cash deposit by the applicant in the sum of $3,000.00 or the filing of a good and sufficient surety bond in the sum of $3,000.00 with the city clerk, to be used as provided in this article, which surety bond shall be approved by the city attorney. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-54. - Revocation of license for noncompliance. 
    If any person or the agent or representative of such person engaged in the bail bond business shall be found guilty of violating this article, the board of commissioners shall have authority to forthwith revoke the privilege license of such person to engage in the bail bond business. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-55. - Solicitation. 
    No person after having been issued a privilege license to engage in the bail bond business shall at any time within the city, by himself, his agents, representatives or employees, solicit business as such bondsman. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-56. - Maximum charges. 
    No person, after having procured a privilege license to engage in the bail bond business, shall charge for his services an amount in excess of 15 percent of the amount of the bail bond. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-57. - Advocating cause, securing settlement for client. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, after having procured a privilege license to engage in the bail bond business, to appear before any judge of any court within the city and advocate the cause of any person for whom such person shall have made a bail bond or approach a solicitor or other prosecuting officer as such advocate of such person or attempt, directly or indirectly, in any manner to secure a settlement of a case pending against a person for whom such person shall have made a bail bond. 
Sec. 18-58. - Forfeiture of bond; depletion of deposit; suspension of license until deposit increased. 
(a)  Upon the final forfeiture of any bond by the municipal court, the city clerk shall issue to the court clerk a check for the amount of the forfeiture, charging the forfeiture against the deposit held for the credit of the person engaging in the bail bond business and, if a surety bond has been filed with the city clerk, shall notify the surety of such final forfeiture and shall demand payment thereon. 
(b)  The person engaging in the bail bond business is required to maintain a deposit of $3,000.00, either in cash or by and through a surety bond, at all times. Upon failure to do so, the privilege license issued for the engaging in the bail bond business shall be suspended until the person complies with this section. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Secs. 18-59-18-74. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DETECTIVES; PRIVATE INVESTIGATORS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- License tax for detective agencies, Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-12-93. 

Sec. 18-75. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Private investigator, detective means anyone engaged by individuals for private protection; a person unofficially engaged in obtaining secret information for the use of and benefit of those who choose to employ him and to pay him compensation; one making an investigation for another when such investigation involves the conduct, life or affairs of the person investigated; one who guards property or keeps it under surveillance; one who collects or attempts to collect debts; one who investigates claims; or one who shadows, keeps under surveillance, investigates or follows one to obtain evidence for or against him. Such terms shall not include public detectives, peace officers or deputy sheriffs; lawyers in the course of the practice of their profession; accountants engaged in the practice of their profession; insurance investigators acting solely in the employ of an insurance company, the insured thereof or agency of such insurance company; one conducting strictly the business of a collection agency, the owner of an account or employees of the owner of the account who collect for the owner thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-76. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to carry on or be engaged in or to advertise as engaging in the vocation, profession or business of a private investigator or detective until a license has been issued or after the license to so engage has been revoked. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-77. - License application; qualifications, bond, photograph. 
(a)  An applicant for a license as a private investigator or detective shall file with the chief of police a written application under oath, outlining in such application the following: 
(1)  Personal data as to the date and place of birth, education, law enforcement experience and business experience; 
(2)  A complete and detailed record and report of all civic suits and criminal cases in which the applicant has been either a party or a witness within the preceding 12 months, specifying the name and location of the court, the nature of the proceeding and the result thereof; 
(3)  The applicant's present address, place of employment and the name and address of at least three city residents as references to the applicant's moral and professional reputation; and 
(4)  The name and address of each employee of the applicant during the past year if applicable. 
(b)  Upon approval of the application, the applicant must submit to the city clerk a surety bond in the amount of $2,000.00 with a guaranty bonding company authorized to do business in the state as surety to indemnify anyone who may be wrongfully injured by the words or acts of the applicant in following the vocation, profession, business or calling of a private investigator or detective. 
(c)  No person shall engage in the business of private investigator or detective unless and until such person shall have attained the age of 21 years. 
(d)  No application for a license as a private investigator or detective shall be received unless and until the application is accompanied by a photograph of the applicant. 
(e)  No person shall be licensed as a private investigator or detective who is not of good personal and professional reputation. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-78. - Investigation and fingerprinting of applicant. 
    The chief of police is directed to make a thorough investigation of each applicant for a license as a private investigator or detective and, after full and complete investigation thereof, including the fingerprinting of the applicant, to report his findings to the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-79. - Certificate of compliance. 
    The privilege license required under this article may be issued only on the certification by the chief of police of compliance with all the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-80. - License issuance; filing of bond. 
    A license to a private investigator or detective shall be issued only on the approval of the board of commissioners, after recommendation by the police chief. On issuance of a license the surety bond filed by the applicant shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-81. - License revocation. 
    The license as a private investigator or detective is granted at the pleasure of the board of commissioners and may be revoked at any time on a majority vote of the board of commissioners for cause. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-82. - Employee license. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in the vocation or profession of private investigator or detective in the city or in its police jurisdiction who does not have the license required by this article. The violation of this section shall be sufficient cause for revocation of the license of the person violating this section. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-83. - Police supervision; carrying weapons. 
    Each private investigator or detective licensed under this article shall be subject to police supervision. Qualifying and being licensed under this article shall not of itself entitle the applicant to carry weapons, concealed or otherwise, in violation of the law. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-84. - Cancellation of bond. 
    Under this article, if the bond of any applicant, investigator or detective shall be cancelled or the surety company guaranteeing the bond shall be declared to be insolvent or in the hands of a receiver, the license of every such applicant, investigator or detective bonded by such company shall be refused or revoked upon notification by the city clerk, until a new bond approved by the city clerk shall have been posted in lieu thereof. If a new bond is not approved and substituted within 12 months after such revocation, a new application must be submitted as set forth in section 18-77 and a new investigation must be conducted by the chief of police as set forth in section 18-78 prior to issuance of a license. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-85. - Badge. 
(a)  The chief of police may prescribe and furnish a numbered badge bearing the inscription "private detective licensed by the City of Dothan," and it shall be unlawful for any person engaging in the business of a private investigator or detective to wear or display any badge other than the badge prescribed and approved by the chief of police or to wear or display that badge after his license shall have expired or been revoked. 
(b)  The chief of police may charge a deposit of $10.00 on each badge furnished to a licensee under this article, which shall be refunded upon the return of the badge to the chief of police. The receipt for the deposit of this money shall be issued by the city clerk. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person licensed under this article to transfer, give, loan or permit another to use any badge assigned by the chief of police to such licensee or to refuse to surrender the badge to the chief of police or a police officer on the termination, expiration or revocation of the license of such private investigator or detective. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Secs. 18-86-18-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - AUCTIONS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Auctions generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 34-1-1 et seq.; limitation on municipalities, Code of Ala. 1975 § 11-51-97. 

DIVISION 1. - PRECIOUS METALS, JEWELRY, CHINA AND GLASS 

Sec. 18-100. - Restrictions; exemptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or dispose of or offer for sale in the city at public auction or to cause or permit to be sold, disposed of or offered for sale in the city at public auction any gold, silver, plated ware, precious stones, watches, clocks, jewelry, bric-a-brac, china or glassware, whether such shall be his own property or whether he shall sell such at auction as agent or employee of others. 
(b)  This division shall not apply to judicial sales or sales by executors or administrators or to sales by or on behalf of licensed pawnbrokers of unredeemed pledges in the manner provided by law or to sales at public auctions, sale of stock on hand of any person who shall, for the period of one year next preceding such sale, have been continuously in business in the city as a retail or wholesale merchant of gold, silver, plated ware, precious stones, watches, clocks, jewelry, bric-a-brac, china or glassware. Such sale at public auction of the stock on hand of such merchants shall not be replenished in anticipation of such auction or pending or during such sale, and the auction shall be held on successive days, Sundays and legal holidays excepted, and shall not continue for more than 30 days within the period of one year. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-101. - Hours of sale. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or dispose of or offer for sale at public auction, between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m., any gold, silver, plated ware, precious stones, watches, clocks, jewelry, bric-a-brac, china or glassware. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-102. - Booster or by-bidder. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to act as a by-bidder or what is commonly known as a "capper" or "booster" at any auction regulated by this division or to offer or make any false bid to buy or pretend to buy any such article sold or offered for sale at any such auction. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-103. - Description of goods sold considered warranties. 
    Any person selling, disposing of or offering for sale at any public auction any such gold, silver, plated ware, precious stones, watches, clocks, jewelry, bric-a-brac, china or glassware shall, in describing the property, be truthful with respect to the character, quality, kind and description of the property and which, for the purpose thereof, shall be considered as warranties. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Secs. 18-104-18-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FARM PRODUCTS 

Sec. 18-111. - Certificate and sworn statement required prior to sale. 
    Before any farmer or other person engaged in the production of farm products shall sell or offer for sale such products of any nature or character in the city, such person shall exhibit to the city clerk or license inspector a certificate of the probate judge of his county that such person is a farmer or is engaged in the production of such farm products. In addition to such certificate, the applicant shall file a sworn statement, when required by the city clerk, giving his name, age and residence; the location of his farm; the number of acres cultivated; and the character and kind of farm products raised thereon and which he desires to sell. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-112. - Penalty for false statements. 
    Any person making a statement as required in section 18-111 which is false shall upon conviction be punished as provided in section 1-4. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Secs. 18-113-18-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - GOING-OUT-OF-BUSINESS SALES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-121. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Fire and other altered goods sale means a sale held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that the sale will offer goods damaged or altered by fire, smoke, water or other means. 
    Going-out-of-business sale means a sale held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that upon the disposal of the stock of goods on hand, the business will cease and be discontinued including, but not limited to, the following sales: adjuster's, adjustment, alteration, assignee's, bankrupt, benefit of administrator's, benefit of creditor's, benefit of trustee's, building coming down, closing, creditor's committee, creditor's end, executor's final days, forced out of business; insolvents, last days, lease expires, liquidation, loss of lease, mortgage sale, receiver's, trustee's; quitting business, forced out. 
    Goods means any goods, wares, merchandise or other property capable of being the object of a sale regulated under this article. 
    Person means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
    Removal of business sale means a sale held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that the person conducting the sale will cease and discontinue business at the place of sale upon disposal of the stock of goods on hand and will then move to and resume business at a new location in the city, or will then continue business from other existing locations in the city. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-122. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person, firm, corporation or association found guilty of violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished in accordance with this Code and the laws of the state. Each day that an offense under this article continues shall be considered a separate offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-123. - Application of article. 
    The provisions of this article are intended to augment and be in addition to the provisions of the general licensing provisions of chapter 18. Where this article imposes a greater restriction upon persons, premises, businesses or practices than is imposed by the provisions of article I of this chapter, this article shall control. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-124. - Exceptions and exemptions. 
(a)  Exception for survivors of businessmen. Upon the death of a person doing business in the city, his heirs, devisees or legatees shall have the right to apply at any time for a license under this article. 
(b)  Persons exempted. The provisions of this article shall not apply to nor affect the following persons: 
(1)  Persons acting pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction; or 
(2)  Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-125. - Restrictions. 
(a)  Interval between sales. Any person who has held a sale, as regulated under this article, at the location stated in the application, within one year last past from the date of such application shall not be granted a license. 
(b)  Restricted location. Where a person applying for a license under this article operates more than one place of business, the license issued shall apply only to the one store, or branch specified in the application, and no other store or branch shall advertise or represent that it is cooperating with it, or in any way participating in the license sale, nor shall the store or branch conducting the licensed sale advertise or represent that any other store or branch is cooperating with it, or participating in any way in the licensed sale unless a separate license is obtained for each location. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Secs. 18-126-18-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 18-131. - Required. 
    A license issued by the city clerk shall be obtained by any person before selling or offering for sale any goods at a sale to be advertised or held out by any means to be one of the following kind: 
(1)  Going-out-of-business sale. 
(2)  Removal of business sale. 
(3)  Fire and other altered stock sale. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-132. - Application. 
    Written information required. A person desiring to conduct a sale regulated by this article shall make a written application to the city clerk, setting forth and containing the following information: 
(1)  The true name and address of the owner of the goods to be the object of the sale. 
(2)  A sworn statement by the legal owner of the business, stating that no additional inventory will be added to the existing inventory during the sale. 
(3)  A description of the place where such sale is to be held. 
(4)  The nature of the occupancy, whether by lease or sublease, and the effective date of termination of such occupancy. 
(5)  The dates of the period of time in which the sale is to be conducted. 
(6)  A full and complete statement of the facts in regard to the sale, including the reason for the urgent and expeditious disposal of goods thereby and the manner in which the sale will be conducted. 
(7)  The means to be employed in advertising such sale, together with the proposed content of any advertisement. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-133. - Conditions; fee. 
    A license shall be issued under this article on the following terms: 
(1)  Licensing period and fee. The license shall authorize the sale described in the application for a period of time and for a license fee as described in this subsection: 
a.  Not more than 30 consecutive calendar days following issuance ..... $150.00 
b.  Not more than 60 consecutive calendar days following issuance ..... $300.00 
    The board of commissioners may authorize the sale to continue for an additional 30 consecutive calendar-day period beyond the 60-day period above, upon receipt of a written request stating the reasons for the request. 
(2)  Nature of sale. The license shall authorize only the one type of sale described in the application at the location named therein. 
(3)  Saleable goods. The license shall authorize only the sale of goods in inventory at the beginning of the sale. 
(4)  Surrender of general license. Upon being issued a license under this article for a going-out-of business sale, the licensee shall surrender to the city clerk all other business licenses they may hold at that time applicable to the location and goods covered by the application for a license under this article. 
(5)  Nontransferability. Any license provided for in this article shall not be assignable or transferable. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-134. - Duties of licensee. 
    It shall be the duty of the licensee to: 
(1)  Adhere to inventory. Make no additions whatsoever during the period of the licensed sale to the stock of goods. 
(2)  Advertise properly. Refrain from employing any untrue, deceptive or misleading advertising. 
(3)  Adhere to advertising. Conduct the licensed sale in strict conformity with any advertising or holding out incident thereto. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Secs. 18-135-18-145. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SECONDHAND GOLD AND SILVER DEALERS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Law enforcement, ch. 54. 

Sec. 18-146. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Applicant means the plural, where applicable, and/or agents, officers, servants or employees of the applicant in the city. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-147. - Applicability of article. 
    The provisions of this article shall be binding upon every employee or agent of the buyer, and it shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any such permit holder or his agents, servants, officers or employees to fail or refuse to carry out the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-148. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person who shall violate any provisions of this article shall be subject to a fine in an amount not to exceed $500.00 or imprisonment, not to exceed six months, or to both fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court trying the case. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-149. - Permit and business license required. 
    It shall be unlawful for anyone to conduct or carry on the business of purchasing secondhand gold or silver, whether in the form of coins, jewelry, household articles or furnishings, personal effects, bric-a-brac, settings for gems, watches, flatware, service sets or other articles of like kind in the city without first obtaining a permit in accordance with the provisions of this article and a city business license in accordance with chapter 18. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-150. - Application for permit-contents. 
    Applicants for a permit under this article shall file with the city clerk a sworn application in writing, in duplicate, on a form to be furnished by the city clerk, which shall give the following information: 
(1)  Name and description of the applicant. 
(2)  Date of birth and driver's license number of the applicant. 
(3)  Full address of the applicant and the length of time the applicant has resided at the address. 
(4)  If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the relationship. 
(5)  A brief description of the nature of the gold and silver buying to be done. 
(6)  The length of time for which the right to do gold and silver buying is desired and the location where such buying is to be done. 
(7)  A photograph of the applicant, taken within 60 days immediately prior to the date of filing the application, which picture shall be two inches by two inches, showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner. 
(8)  The fingerprints of the applicant, and the names of at least two reliable property owners of the county, who will certify as to the applicant's good character and business respectability or, in lieu of the names of such references, such other available evidence as to the good character and business responsibility of the applicant, as will enable an investigator to properly evaluate such character and business responsibility. 
(9)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any municipal criminal ordinance in any state, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefore. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-151. - Same-Investigation fee. 
    At the time of filing the application for the permit, a fee of $10.00 shall be paid to the city clerk to cover the cost of an investigation of the facts state therein. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-152. - Same-Investigation of applicant; issuance or denial or permit; appeal. 
    Upon receipt of an application the original shall be referred to the chief of police, who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and moral character to be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the public good. If, as a result of such an investigation, the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory or if he does not otherwise qualify under the provisions of this article, the chief of police shall endorse on such application his disapproval and the reason for the same and return the application to the city clerk who shall notify the applicant that the application is disapproved and that no permit will be issued. If, as a result of such investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, and the applicant otherwise qualifies under this article, the chief of police shall endorse on the application his approval and return the application to the city clerk who shall deliver to the applicant a permit, in the same manner as to other licenses of the city. If the permit is disapproved, the applicant may appeal to the board of city commissioners within 14 days. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-153. - Contents of permit; display of license. 
    The permit shall contain the signature of the city clerk and shall show the name, address and photograph of the licensee, the date of issuance and length of time the same shall be operative, as well as the license number. Such license must be displayed at all times whenever the applicant conducts business. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-154. - Registration of permit holders. 
    Each permit holder under this article shall promptly, after the beginning of business, register with the chief of police, in a book kept for that purpose, the permit holder's name, address and every place where business is carried on or property stored. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-155. - Record of permits issued. 
    The city clerk shall keep a permanent record of all permits issued under this article. 
Sec. 18-156. - Records to be kept by buyers; transcripts to be furnished to chief of police. 
    Each applicant who secures a license under this article for purchasing gold or silver in any form set out in section 18-150 shall: 
(1)  Keep a book in which shall be entered promptly at the time of purchase a brief description of the articles or property purchased or a descriptive photo thereof, the date and hour of the purchase and a brief description of the person from who the purchase is made, together with the address, driver's license number, sex, race and date of birth of such person. Each entry of such transaction shall be serially numbered on the book at the time of making the entry. 
(2)  On every day, before the hour of 10:00 a.m., deliver to the chief of police, upon a form provided by him, a legible transcript of the business done during the business day immediately preceding the filing of the transcript. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-157. - Inspection of records of permit holders. 
    The books and records kept by each permit holder of the articles described in section 18-156 shall be open for inspection by the chief of police or by any officer of the police department of the city at all times, and the permit holder and his agents and employees shall at all times exhibit the book to such officers on request. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Cross reference- Law enforcement, ch. 54. 
Sec. 18-158. - Identification of articles purchased. 
    Each permit holder shall attach to or place on each such article purchased a tag or other identifying mark or label numbered to correspond with the serial number of the book entry required by section 18-156; except, where small articles are bought in bulk and/or are too numerous to conveniently tag or mark, an identifying number shall be placed on the container or wrapper in which all the articles are kept or placed. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-159. - Articles to be held by permit holder after purchase. 
    The property of the kind described in section 18-149 shall be held in the same form, shape or condition in which they were purchased, without mutilation, melting, reduction to block or lump form, or destruction of the form thereof, for a period of 72 hours after the hour when the permit holder reports the purchase to the chief of police during which time such articles shall be open to inspection or examination by the chief of police, or such officers of the police department as may be delegated to make such examination or inspection, unless permission for a change in the form or sale of such article is obtained in writing from the chief of police after the filing of the report required by section 18-156. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Secs. 18-160-18-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Peddlers and itinerant vendors license, Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-12-139. 

Sec. 18-176. - Use of streets and sidewalks for residential door-to-door canvassing. 
(a)  Generally. The following practices very often become nuisances and therefore are of such public concern for the preservation of the privacy and safety of the citizens of the city that they must be regulated: 
(1)  Going in and upon private residences by peddlers, canvassers, solicitors and transient vendors of merchandise, not having been requested or invited so to do by the owner or occupant, for the purpose of disposing of the same; 
(2)  Peddling, selling of goods, wares or merchandise upon public or private streets or sidewalks; and 
(3)  Soliciting money, services or orders for the sale of goods, wares or merchandise upon public or private streets or sidewalks. 
(b)  Compliance with city ordinances. Before any person or organization shall engage in any of the practices named in subsection (a) of this section, they must comply with all ordinances of the city and must also obtain from the license division an identification card in accordance with the provisions of subsection (d) of this section. Such card shall extend not longer than 30 days. 
(c)  Application requirements. Any applicant engaged in any activity described in subsections (a)(1), (a)(2) and/or (a)(3) of this section must file with the license division an application in writing which shall give the following information: 
(1)  Name and physical description; 
(2)  Permanent and local address and, in the case of itinerant merchants and transient vendors, the local address from which proposed sales will be made; 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the practice; 
(4)  Name and address of the firm for or on whose behalf the orders are solicited or the supplier of the goods involved; 
(5)  Length of time for which the permit is desired; 
(6)  Statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any criminal offense involving moral turpitude and, if so, the nature of the offense and penalty imposed; 
(7)  Motor vehicle make, model, year, color and registration number if the vehicle shall be used in the proposed solicitation; and 
(8)  Social Security number. 
(d)  Identification card; issuance; fee; display; revocation. Upon the furnishing of the information required under subsection (a) of this section, such applicant shall be issued an identification card for each agent or solicitor used for such solicitation, for which a $3.00 fee shall be required, by the license division within five working days after applying therefore, unless the information furnished in compliance therewith shows that the applicant has been convicted of a felony or if the investigation thereof reveals that the applicant has falsified any information required in the section. All identification cards shall upon demand be exhibited to any police officer or any other city official and shall be displayed to any person who is being solicited. Any identification card granted under this chapter may be revoked by the municipal court after the filing of the information by the prosecuting attorney and a hearing thereon for any of the following cases: 
(1)  Any violation of this section; 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation or incorrect statement made in the course of carrying on the activity; 
(3)  Conviction of a felony; or 
(4)  Conducting the activity in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
(e)  Penalty for violation of section. A person who violates any provision of this section, upon conviction, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and fined not less than $1.00 nor more than $250.00 or shall be imprisoned for not more than 30 days, or both. 
(f)  Exemption. Nothing in this section shall be construed so as to include a bona fide nonprofit charitable organization which offers proof that such organization is exempt from federal income taxation or equivalent proof of its nonprofit charitable status. Any bona fide nonprofit charitable organization shall submit such proof to the license division of the city prior to engaging in any solicitation activities described in this section. It shall be the responsibility of the license division to contact the police department and inform the police department as to solicitation activities by such exempt organization. 
(g)  Restricted hours. Peddling, soliciting or selling upon streets and sidewalks or residential door-to-door canvassing, as provided by this section shall be prohibited between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m., Monday through Saturday, and on Sunday and legal holidays. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86. 
Sec. 18-177. - Entering premises without invitation declared nuisance. 
    The practice of going in and upon private residences in the city by solicitors, peddlers, hawkers, itinerant merchants or transient vendors of merchandise and printed matter, not having been requested or invited to do so by the owner or occupant of the private residence, for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise, and printed matter or for the purpose of disposing of or peddling or hawking the same or for the purpose of seeking an invitation for such purposes, or for any such purpose herein cited when a sign is placed near the doorknob or doorbell requesting no disturbance by solicitors, is hereby declared to be a nuisance and punishable as such as a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-178. - Telephone solicitations. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Charitable telephone solicitations campaign means any course of conduct, including social functions, dances, barbecues, etc., whereby any person, organization, society, association, corporation or church, religious society or other religious sect, group, or any member thereof solicits, by telephone, financial assistance, property or donations of any kind, or sells or offers to sell any article, tag, service, emblem, publication, ticket, advertisement, subscription or anything of value on a plea or representation that such sale or solicitation or the proceeds there from are for a charitable, educational, patriotic, philanthropic, religious or political purpose. 
    Commercial telephone solicitations campaign means any course of conduct whereby any person, organization or society, or any agent, member or representative thereof, including professional fundraisers, solicits, by telephone, orders for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise, service or printed matter, or for the purpose of disposing of, peddling or hawking the same. 
(b)  Registration and application for appropriate license. It shall be unlawful to conduct any telephone solicitations campaign utilizing telephones at locations within the city limits of the city to deliver or obtain anything of value in the city unless: 
(1)  For charitable telephone solicitations, the persons or groups enumerated in subsection (a) of this section shall have first registered in compliance with the terms of this section. 
(2)  For commercial telephone solicitations, the persons or groups enumerated in subsection (a) of this section shall have first obtained a business license from the city license division. 
(3)  The terms of this provision shall not apply to: 
a.  Any organization which solicits funds solely from its own members or from its own assemblies; or 
b.  The solicitation of advertising by daily or weekly newspapers, radio, television, yellow pages and outdoor advertising. 
(c)  City business license required for commercial telephone solicitations. A commercial solicitation campaign may commence not less than ten days following completion of the application with the city. Such application shall be sworn to by the applicant and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The full name of the organization registering to solicit by telephone, and the address of the headquarters in the city; if the organization is a subsidiary or other affiliate of an organization having its principal office outside the city, the name and address of the parent organization or corporation. 
(2)  The names and addresses of all officers and directors or trustees of the organization and the name and city of residence of all officers, directors or trustees of the parent organization, if any. 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the persons who will be in charge of conducting the telephone commercial solicitations campaign. 
(4)  The period, within which such telephone commercial solicitations campaign shall be conducted, including the proposed dates for the beginning and ending of such campaign. 
(5)  The name and address of any person, who will either be in charge of the telephone solicitation or in charge of the groups who solicit or who will do any soliciting, who has been convicted of a criminal offense involving moral turpitude. The following information shall be furnished with respect to each conviction: 
a.  Date of conviction. 
b.  Location of conviction. 
c.  Nature of offense. 
d.  Sentence upon conviction. 
(d)  Waiting period; additional information. A charitable solicitation campaign may commence not less than ten days following the completion of registration with the city. Such application shall be sworn to by the applicant in addition to the information contained in subsection (c) of this section. Such registration shall contain the following information as well: 
(1)  The purpose for which the gross receipts derived from such solicitations or other activities are to be used. 
(2)  If the registrant is a charitable corporation or other organization, proof of its current status as an organization to which contributions are tax-deductible for federal income tax purposes. 
(e)  License fee. Every application shall be accompanied by a license fee of $50.00. 
(f)  Form of license. The city license division shall prescribe the form of the license. However, each such license shall be printed in black and shall contain the following: "The issuance of this license is not an endorsement by the City of Dothan or any of its officers or employees." Each license shall bear a registration number which is the same as the file in which the application is contained. 
(g)  Reports to be filed by commercial telephone solicitations. All persons or organizations registering under this chapter as professional fundraisers shall furnish to the city, within 30 days after the telephone solicitations campaign has been completed, a detailed report and financial statement showing the amount of funds raised by the telephone solicitations campaign; and the amount expended in collecting such funds, including a detailed report of the wages, fees, commissions and expenses paid to any person in connection with such solicitation and the disposition of the balance of the funds collected by the campaign; provided, however, that the city may extend the time for the report required by this section for an additional period of 30 days upon proof that the filing of the report within the time specified will work unnecessary hardship on the solicitor. The solicitor shall make available to the city all books, records and papers whereby the accuracy of the report required by this section may be investigated. All financial statements and reports and all applications submitted by any applicant or registrant under this section shall be made, prepared and interpreted in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. 
(h)  Times of soliciting. Charitable and commercial telephone solicitation on any telephone located in the city is prohibited between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m., Monday through Saturday, and on Sunday and legal holidays. 
(i)  Disclosure of telephone solicitor's employer's name and address. All professional fundraisers engaged in charitable telephone solicitations in the city shall disclose to potential donors his employer's name and address, and the charity for which he is soliciting. 
(j)  Penalty for violation of section. Any person found guilty of violation of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-4. Each offense and each day's continuance of the offense shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Secs. 18-179-185. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - POOL AND BILLIARDS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Billiard rooms generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 34-6-1 et seq. 

Sec. 18-186. - Compliance with state law; approval of location. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, open or operate any public pool hall, pool room, billiard hall or billiard parlor and no license shall be issued for the privilege of operating such a business until all laws of the state pertaining thereto have been complied with and the proposed location is first approved by the board of commissioners, such approval being made at a regular meeting of the board and evidence thereof being shown in the minutes of the meeting. 
(b)  This section does not apply to coin-operated devices in restaurants or other places which are not pool or billiard parlors. 
Secs. 18-187-18-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - RACES 

Sec. 18-191. - License and insurance required. 
(a)  As used in this section, the terms "conduct" and "conducted" shall include any preparation for drag races or races in which motor vehicles are used. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or permit to be conducted upon lands under his control drag races or races in which motor vehicles are used without first securing a city license. To secure such license, the applicant shall file a certificate or satisfactory evidence with the city clerk that such person has in effect liability insurance to cover personal injury and property damage to participants, spectators and owners of property both on or off the grounds where such races will be conducted. The amount of the liability insurance shall be as follows: 
(1)  Spectators' and participants' liability, $100,000.00 combined single limit. 
(2)  Spectators' and participants' liability, $900,000.00 combined single limit excess of $100,000.00. 
(c)  The insurance required shall provide that the city clerk shall be notified in writing 30 days before cancellation or change in the coverage of such insurance. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Secs. 18-192-18-195. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - RESTAURANTS AND OTHER EATING ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 18-196. - Certificate from county health officer prerequisite to issuance of license. 
    No license shall be issued by the city clerk for the operation of a cafe, lunch stand or eating establishment of any kind until the application for the license is accompanied by a certificate from the county health officer that such establishment has been inspected by him and the establishment meets the requirements of public health laws. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Secs. 18-197-18-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Transient merchants generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 34-35-1 et seq.; transient vendors license, Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-12-174; bond required, Code of Ala. 1975, § 40-23-24. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-201. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Transient merchants means and includes all persons, both principals and agents, who engage in or conduct in this city, either in one locality or in traveling from place to place, a temporary or transient business of selling or soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares or merchandise, with the intention of continuing in such business in the city for a period of not more than 180 days, and who rent, lease, use or occupy, either in whole or in part, for the purpose of carrying on such business, any room, building, area within the Dothan Civic Center or any other public or privately-owned building, any lot or parcel of land, any motor vehicle, including trucks and semi-trailers for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise. The provisions of this article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Sales of agricultural produce licensed under this Code. 
(2)  Wholesale sales to licensed businesses, trades or professions. 
(3)  Sales to licensed businesses, trades or professions where such items are not for resale. 
(4)  Where no license may be collected under the provisions of the constitution or laws of the United States. 
(5)  Sales occurring at art shows, antique shows, craft shows, coin shows, trade shows or other shows of a similar kind or description where such art shows, antique shows, craft shows, coin shows, trade shows or other shows of a similar kind or description are organized by and under the authority, control and supervision of a bona fide and commonly recognized charitable or religious organization or a shopping mall association or corporation located with the city. 
(6)  Sales occurring at art shows, antique shows, craft shows of a similar kind or description, held within the Dothan Civic Center or other facility in the city where such shows and sales take place under the authority, control and supervision of the city, the county or the state. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-202. - Reports of sales. 
    All transient merchants shall make a verified report of sales to the city clerk within seven days of the close of business. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-203. - Purpose of sale; statement of persons from whom and where goods were purchased. 
    A transient merchant shall not advertise, represent or hold forth a sale of goods, wares or merchandise as an insurance, bankrupt, insolvent, assignee, trustee, estate, executor, administrator, receiver, manufacturer's wholesale, canceled order or misfit sale or closing-out, or a sale of any goods damaged by smoke, fire, water or otherwise, unless before doing he shall: 
(1)  State in writing under oath to the revenue officer at the time he makes application for a license, all the facts relating to the reason and character of such special sales, so advertised, held forth or represented, including: 
a.  A statement of the names of the persons from whom such goods, wares or merchandise were purchased, and the date of delivery of such goods, wares or merchandise to the person applying for license; 
b.  The place where such goods, wares or merchandise were taken last; and 
c.  Such details necessary to exactly locate and fully identify all goods, wares or merchandise to be sold; 
(2)  Make such further disclosure to and give such information as may be required by the city clerk; and 
(3)  Include in such statement names and residences of the owners in whose interest the business is conducted and whether conducted as an individual, firm, association or corporation. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-204. - Violations of article. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any: 
(1)  Transient merchant to sell or exhibit for sale, either at public or private sale, any goods, wares or merchandise without first complying with the provisions of this article. 
(2)  Transient merchant to make any false statements in reference to the matter required. 
(3)  Transient merchant to fail or refuse to comply with the requirements of any of the provisions of this article. 
(4)  Person, whether principal or agent, who by circular, handbill, newspaper, poster or in any manner, to advertise such sales as contemplated in this article before proper license is issued to such transient merchant and before he has complied with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Nothing in this article shall be construed as abridging or denying the right and power of the city commission to refuse or withhold the granting of any license or to revoke the license, if granted, to a transient merchant upon any hearing thereof when in the discretion of the commission on the basis of the disclosures as aforesaid, or from other information deemed by them sufficient, such action as may be deemed necessary or proper to protect and safeguard the public from imposition, mischief or fraud. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-205. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any violation of this article shall be considered a misdemeanor and shall be punishable as set forth in section 1-4. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Secs. 18-206-18-215. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 18-216. - Application. 
    At least 14 days prior to the holding of such sale or solicitation, every such transient merchant shall furnish to the city clerk a verified license application setting out the following: 
(1)  Name and address of the applicant and also the name of the true owner if the applicant is not such true owner of the goods, wares or merchandise to be sold. 
(2)  Name, location and time of the proposed sale or solicitation. 
(3)  Inventory of the goods, wares or merchandise on hand and on order, which the applicant intends to offer for sale at such sale. The inventory shall show the quantity, kind or grade of each item, the wholesale cost thereof, the price at which each item is proposed to be sold and the total wholesale and retail value of the inventory based on the foregoing, and if sales are to be made other than from inventory, a copy of the catalogue or other sales materials and/or a listing of the samples to be displayed. 
(4)  A statement of the amount of gross receipts realized from each sale conducted in the city by the applicant, and the dates thereof, if such sale was within the preceding five years. 
(5)  Such other information as the city clerk may prescribe. 
(6)  Address of any permanent place of business in the state, or if there is no permanent place of business in the state, a copy of the certificate of the secretary of the state evidencing the fact that the dealer, if a corporation, has qualified to do business in the state and the name and address of its agent for the service of process in the state. If the applicant is not a qualified corporation and has no permanent business address, the application shall contain the applicant's social security number. 
(7)  Provide the city with a state sales tax account number that must be reported to the state for sales made in this city. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-217. - Fee. 
    All transient dealers as defined in section 18-201 shall pay a license fee based on the following schedule: 
If anticipated sales are: $5,000.00 or less $ 100.00 More than $5,000.00 but less than $10,000.00   200.00 More than $10,000.00 but less than $25,000.00   400.00 More than $25,000.00 but less than $50,000.00   600.00 More than $50,000.00 but less than $100,000.00   800.00 Over $100,000.00  1,000.00 Plus one-tenth of one percent of the gross receipts.  
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-218. - Deposits and bond. 
(a)  Every applicant for a transient merchant's license shall execute and file for review by the city attorney a good and sufficient bond for each event as follows: 
If anticipated sales are: $5,000.00 or less $ 2,500.00 More than $5,000.00 but less than $10,000.00   5,000.00 More than $10,000.00 but less than $25,000.00   7,500.00 More than $25,000.00 but less than $50,000.00   10,000.00 More than $50,000.00 but less than $100,000.00   12,500.00 Over $100,000.00   25,000.00  
Or ten percent of anticipated sales, whichever is greater. 
(b)  The surety thereon shall be a surety company authorized to do business in the state and approved by the city attorney and shall: 
(1)  Be payable to the city, to the extent that any taxes or fines as determined by the city clerk to be due are not paid, and, upon judicial determination, to those authorized to file suit there under; 
(2)  Be conditioned upon faithful observance of all the conditions of this article and the payment of city license, and all state and local taxes due or to be withheld and paid by the licensee under this article; and 
(3)  Also indemnify any purchaser at such sale who suffers any loss by reason of defective merchandise or any misrepresentation in such sale. 
(c)  The bond shall also provide that: 
(1)  The city or its authorized representative, county and the state may file suit in their own name against the licensee and/or the surety on the bond for any taxes, fees or fines due from the licensee which are not paid within 30 days of the termination; 
(2)  Any purchaser at such sale may maintain an action against the licensee and/or the surety for claims arising from such sale; and 
(3)  It shall continue in effect for one year after the termination of the sale for which it is made and until all actions are concluded and the judgments, if any, have been paid and fully satisfied, or the amount of the bond exhausted by such payments. 
(d)  This bond shall be in addition to all deposits required under the ordinances of the city, including but not limited to the sales and use tax ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Secs. 18-219-18-225. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - TREE CUTTERS[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference- Vegetation, ch. 106. 

Sec. 18-226. - Cleanup bond. 
    Under this article, a bond of $250.00 cash or a surety bond of $1,000.00 shall be required to ensure removal of debris to a satisfactory place of disposal. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-227. - Insurance. 
    No license shall be issued for the cutting of trees until the applicant deposits with the city clerk a general liability insurance policy in an amount of at least $50,000.00. The insurance policy shall cover liability to the person as well as to property. The policy must provide for a 30-day notice to the city clerk prior to cancellation. The requirement for insurance shall not apply to persons engaged in the business of tree stump grinding only. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-228. - Permit required; term. 
    Under this article, a permit must be obtained by the licensee or any person engaged in the cutting of trees for profit or other consideration prior to the commencement of the removal of any tree. Each permit shall be good for 30 days and shall only be valid for one location. A permit shall not be required for the grinding of tree stumps. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-229. - Permit fee; penalty for failure to obtain. 
    A fee of $5.00 shall be charged for each permit issued under this article. Failure to obtain a permit prior to beginning work shall result in a penalty of $50.00 in addition to the permit fee. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-230. - Other charges. 
    Under this article, any services required of the city in support of the licensee's business shall be billed to such licensee at the customary rates charged by the city. Such services would include removal or protection of city facilities or services that may be endangered by services rendered by the licensee. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Secs. 18-231-18-240. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - PAWN SHOPS 

Sec. 18-241. - Defined. 
    Any person who lends money or takes personal property, including pistols, as a pledge, or who buys personal property, including pistols, with the agreement or understanding that the same may be redeemed. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-242. - Reporting in general. 
    Every pawnbroker within the city shall report to the chief of police, a description of every article or thing received in pawn, pledge, trade, purchase, or consignment on the business day immediately preceding the filing of the report, in a manner and time as set out herein. Reports shall be made every business day except Saturday and Sunday. Business and transactions done on Saturday or Sunday will be reported on the following Monday. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-243. - Computerized reporting. 
(a)  Every pawnbroker will report all transactions from the previous business day, no later than 4:00 p.m. the next business day. Transactions from Saturday and Sunday shall be reported no later than 4:00 p.m. on the following Monday. The reporting shall be via computer desk or modern transmission as specified by the chief of police. The reporting shall be in a format as specified by the chief of police. The reporting shall be in a format as specified by the chief of police to facilitate loading electronically into the Dothan Police Department's system for locating, lost, stolen, and sought-after property. 
(b)  The chief of police may restrict the scope of items reported at his or her discretion. Items reported electronically shall not also be reported on paper unless requested by the chief of police. Reports filed which contain errors that require correction by the police department staff shall result in a fee of $1.00 per item charged and billed to the appropriate pawnbroker. 
(c)  After establishing an electronic format, the chief of police must have good cause to make any changes and facilitate a minimum of 30 days for pawnbrokers to comply. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-244. - Violations. 
    Failure to comply with any section of this section shall result in the revocation of the pawnbroker and/or business license issued by the city and such failure to comply also constitutes a misdemeanor. Each day the violation continues, a separate misdemeanor offense occurs. Failure to pay error fees shall also result in the revocation of the pawnbroker and/or business license issued by the city and shall constitute a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Secs. 18-245-18-270. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVI. - YARD SALES 

Sec. 18-271. - Defined. 
    For the purposes of this article, the term "yard sale" shall mean and include all sales entitled "yard sale," "garage sale," "lawn sale," "attic sale," "rummage sale," "flea market sale," or any other similar casual sale of tangible personal property whereby there is a display and offer for sale of any goods, wares or merchandise, on the premises of any residential lot within the city limits, which goods, wares or merchandise offered for sale are the household furnishings or personal possessions of the persons conducting the sale and residing at the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-272. - Property acquired for resale not to be offered for sale at garage sales. 
    The offer for sale by means of a yard sale of property which has been specifically acquired for resale, or the consignment of which has been accepted for display and offer for sale at a yard sale is specifically prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-273. - Temporary uses. 
    A resident of the city may conduct sales commonly known as yard sales at the resident's dwelling, or at the dwelling of another resident of the city, under conditions specified herein below: 
(1)  Not more than three yard sales shall be held at any one dwelling during the calendar year. A fourth yard sale or "estate sale" may be permitted after the individual wishing to conduct the sale provides the name of the estate as filed in the office of the judge of probate in Houston County. 
(2)  No person shall participate in, including having property sold at more than three yard sales in the city during the calendar year, regardless of whether such additional sale is held at the individual's dwelling or at the dwelling of another person. 
(3)  Yard sales shall be limited to two days in duration, which days must be consecutive, for a period of not more than ten hours each day. Inclement weather may extend the period of time equal to the days lost provided notice is given to the business license office within two working days. 
(4)  No foods may be sold. 
(5)  The provisions of the City of Dothan Code of Ordinances subsection 14-516(13) Standards for signs shall apply. Signs may be posted for a period not to exceed four consecutive days, including the day or days of the sale itself. All signs must be removed within 24 hours after the conclusion of the sale. Any signage placed on other than authorized property shall be subject to seizure without notice. 
(6)  Yard sales conducted on the common area of apartment buildings and mobile home parks require a permission letter from the property manager. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-274. - Permit required; term. 
    Under this article, a permit must be obtained from the business license office at least three business days prior to holding a yard sale. This permit may be obtained in the business license office or via telephone, fax or mail. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-275. - Penalty for failure to obtain a permit. 
    Failure to obtain a permit prior to holding a yard sale shall result in the issuance of a notice of noncompliance. Issuance of a notice of noncompliance shall carry a penalty of $10.00. Any person failing to obtain a permit and pay the penalty within five business days after a notice of noncompliance is issued shall be in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-276. - Posting of permit. 
    The permit issued by the business license office shall be available for inspection by the city officials at the yard sale location. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-277. - Monitoring and enforcement procedures. 
    Any police officer, revenue officer, or zoning officer is hereby authorized to make inspections of any yard or structure in which a yard sale is being conducted to determine whether such yard sale is being conducted in compliance with this section. Such inspections may be made during the days and hours of the sale. The zoning officer, police officer or revenue officer may, but shall not be required to give notice of the inspection. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 18-278. - Violations. 
    Violations of the chapter are punishable as provided under the terms of section 1-4 of the City of Dothan Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2007-393, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Chapter 22 - CEMETERIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, ch. 46; planning, ch. 70; zoning, ch. 114. 
State Law reference- Cemeteries generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-40 et seq. 

Sec. 22-1. - Interment or removal records. 
    Each funeral director, mortician, undertaker or vault company, if no funeral director, mortician or undertaker is in charge in case of removals, shall file a record of interment or removal of the remains of any decedent in the city engineer's office within 48 hours of interment or removal, keep a copy in his files as a permanent record and furnish a copy to the relative of the decedent signing the record. The record shall show: 
(1)  The grave space, lot, block numbers and section of the city cemetery in or from which interment or removal, the date and approximate hour, shall be made. 
(2)  The funeral director, mortician or undertaker in charge, and by whom the grave will be opened and closed. 
(3)  The age, sex, color, residence and date of death. 
(4)  An interment or removal authorization record shall be signed by a relative of the decedent having authority to make such authorization, agreeing to hold the city harmless from any liability on account of such interment or removal, and witnessed by representatives of the funeral director, mortician or undertaker, or of the vault company in case of removals where there is no funeral director. 
(Code 1977, § 6-1) 
Sec. 22-2. - Erection, construction, establishment of tombstones, monuments, coping, or other structure-Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, construct or establish any monument, tombstone, coping or other structure, in the city cemetery of the city, without first obtaining a permit. Such permit shall be first approved by the city engineer. 
(Code 1977, § 6-2) 
Sec. 22-3. - Same-Removal by city authorized on failure to obtain permit. 
    Any monument, tombstone or other structure, constructed or placed in the city cemetery without first obtaining a permit, may be torn down and removed by the city at the expense of the person placing or erecting the same. 
(Code 1977, § 6-3) 
Chapter 26 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; mayor, § 2-71 et seq.; emergency services, ch. 34; floods, ch. 42. 

Sec. 26-1. - Findings. 
    From time to time conditions of extreme peril to the safety of persons and property will arise within the city caused by fire, flood, storm, epidemic, earthquake, drought, energy shortage, war or other matters of public calamity warranting and necessitating the proclamation of the existence of a local emergency. 
Sec. 26-2. - Proclamation of emergency. 
    The mayor, when the existence of appropriate circumstances demand, may declare a local emergency when any of the events referred to in section 26-1 occur and conditions of extreme peril warrant and necessitate the proclamation of the existence of a local emergency. 
Sec. 26-3. - Duties, powers of emergency management personnel. 
    During the existence of a local emergency, the city manager or his designee as head of the emergency organization of the city shall have those powers and duties as are prescribed by state law and by ordinance of the city. 
Chapter 30 - COURTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Settlement procedures for minor animal control violations, § 10-81 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 30-1-30-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL COURT 

Sec. 30-31. - Establishment. 
    A municipal court was established effective December 27, 1977, and is hereby continued in force for the city, pursuant to the provisions of Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-1 et seq., and referred to in this article as "the court." 
(Code 1977, § 8-1) 
Sec. 30-32. - Jurisdiction. 
    The court shall have jurisdiction of all prosecutions for the breach of city ordinances within its corporate limits and police jurisdiction. This jurisdiction shall also extend to all prosecutions for violations of state offenses committed within the corporate limits and police jurisdiction of the city where such offenses have been made offenses against the city. 
(Code 1977, § 8-2) 
Sec. 30-33. - Prosecutorial services. 
    The city shall furnish prosecutorial services in the municipal court and in appeals from such judgments and orders. The municipal judge should not act as judge and prosecutor unless the defendant knowingly and voluntarily waives the right to an independent prosecutor. 
(Code 1977, § 8-11) 
Sec. 30-34. - Time and place of holding court. 
    The court shall convene at such time and place as the board of commissioners may determine with the advice of the municipal court judge. 
(Code 1977, § 8-3) 
Sec. 30-35. - Municipal court judge. 
(a)  Appointment; number. The court shall consist of one municipal judge to be appointed by a vote of a majority of the members of the commission. The judge shall be appointed for a term of four years. The judge shall be eligible for reappointment upon the expiration of his/her term, and shall hold office until his/her successor is appointed and qualified. 
(b)  Qualifications. The municipal judge must be licensed to practice law in the state and must be a qualified elector of the state. No judge shall be otherwise employed in any capacity by the city during his term of office except as provided in subsection (f) of this section. 
(c)  Vacancies; filling; acting judges. The office of the municipal judge shall be vacant if he dies, resigns or is removed, and vacancies shall be filled by the commission in the same manner as original appointments are made. Any person so appointed shall be eligible to serve two years from the date of appointment. Until such person is appointed, or in the absence from the city of a judge, the mayor shall have the authority to designate a person, licensed to practice law in the state and a qualified elector with all power and authority of a duly appointed municipal judge. No such acting judge may serve for more than 30 successive days or a total of 60 days in any calendar year; provided, however, that when the duly appointed municipal judge is disqualified pursuant to the state constitution, the time of service limitations for acting judges shall not apply during such disqualification. 
(d)  Oath of office. The municipal judge shall, before assuming office, take and sign the oath provided by the state constitution, and a copy shall be filed in the office of the secretary of state, the administrative director of courts and the city clerk. 
(e)  Grounds for disqualification. The municipal judge shall be subject to all grounds of disqualification from hearing specific cases as are applicable to circuit court judges. 
(Code 1977, § 8-4; Ord. No. 2000-339, § 1, 11-7-00) 
Sec. 30-36. - Compensation of judge. 
    The annual salary of the municipal judge shall be fixed by resolution of the commission and shall be payable in biweekly installments. This salary shall not be diminished during the judge's term of office. 
(Code 1977, § 8-5) 
Sec. 30-37. - Powers of the court. 
(a)  The municipal judge shall have the power to admit to bail any person charged with the violation of any municipal ordinance by requiring an appearance bond, with good security, to be approved by the municipal judge or his designee, in an amount not to exceed $500.00 with a maximum bond of $5,000.00 for the charge of driving under the influence of alcohol or controlled substances, or the maximum bond for an offense as authorized by the legislature of the state. The court may require the person to enter into a new undertaking if it appears that the original undertaking was insufficient when entered into or has since become insufficient. The judge or a magistrate operating under the court's direction may, in his discretion, admit to bail minor misdemeanants on a personal recognizance bond, conditioned on the appearance of such persons before him on a day named therein to answer the charges preferred against them. Rule 7 of the ARCP, as amended, is adopted by reference in this section as if fully set forth. The forms of bail shall comply with Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 15-13-20 and 15-13-21, or as recommended by the administrative office of courts. Only pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-1-4 and Rule 19 of the ARJA, as amended, may a police officer release on recognizance a person charged with a minor traffic infraction. Police officers may not accept a cash deposit in lieu of bail. 
(b)  The municipal judge shall have the authority to punish any person convicted of violating any municipal ordinance as provided in section 1-4; provided, however, that for driving under the influence of alcohol or controlled substances, a fine of not more than $5,000.00 and/or a sentence of imprisonment or hard labor for not more than one year may be imposed. The penalty imposed on a corporation shall consist of the fine only, plus costs of court. No prisoner shall be required to perform hard labor if he is declared by a duly qualified physician to be physically unfit at such time. 
(c)  The municipal judge in his judgment may provide that if a fine and costs are not paid within the time prescribed, the defendant, unless indigent, shall work out the amount of the judgment under the direction of the municipal authority allowing not less than $15.00 for each day's service. The provisions of Code of Ala. 1975, § 14-6-22, on housing, maintenance and medical costs apply in municipal court. 
(d)  Upon each conviction in municipal court, there shall be taxed against the defendant as a court cost for the benefit of the city the sum of $50.00. There shall also be taxed as costs the additional costs and fees imposed by the statutes of the state, and the latter such costs and fees shall be remitted pursuant to the state statutes. All costs taxed for the city, as provided in this subsection, shall be paid into the city treasury. Pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-7.1, as amended, $40.00 of each court cost taxed against a defendant shall be deposited into a special account designated as the corrections fund, and is to be used solely for the operation and maintenance of the municipal jail or court complex. 
    Also, a fee of $8.00 shall be charged for issuance of a subpoena upon conviction of defendant. In the event the defendant is declared indigent, this fee may be waived. 
(e)  Upon conviction, the court may, upon a showing of inability to make immediate payment of fines and costs, accept the defendant's bond with or without surety and with waiver of exemptions as to personalty, payable within 90 days, upon nonpayment of which execution may issue as upon judgments in state courts. 
(f)  The municipal judge shall have the authority to continue the case from time to time to permit the fine and costs to be paid; remit fines, costs and fees; impose intermittent sentences; establish work release programs; require attendance of educational, corrective or rehabilitative programs; suspend or revoke driving privileges for such times and under such conditions as provided by law; and order hearings to determine the competency of the defendant to stand trial. 
(g)  All cases in municipal court shall be tried by the judge without a jury. The victim of a criminal offense shall be entitled to be present during court proceedings. 
(h)  The judge may suspend execution of sentence and place a defendant on probation for varying periods of time, not to exceed two years, under the procedures and conditions set out in Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-13, as may be amended. 
(i)  The judge may administer oaths, compel the attendance of witnesses and compel the production of books and papers; punish by fine not exceeding $50.00 and/or imprisonment not exceeding five days any person found and adjudged to be in contempt of court; and shall have power coextensive with the jurisdiction of the district court to issue writs and other process, to approve and declare bail and bonds forfeited, and to enforce forfeitures according to Code of Ala. 1975, § 15-13-80 et seq., as may be amended. The judge shall designate any other court officials who shall be authorized to approve appearance and appeal bonds. 
(j)  The court shall take judicial notice of the ordinances of the city. 
(k)  The sheriff of the county and all city law enforcement officers shall obey the municipal judge having legal authority in faithfully executing the warrants and processes committed to them for service according to their mandates. 
(Code 1977, § 8-6; Ord. No. 97-126, § 1, 4-15-97; Ord. No. 2001-254, § 1, 8-21-01) 
Sec. 30-38. - Warrants. 
    The municipal judge is authorized to issue arrest and search warrants upon affidavit for municipal ordinance violations returnable to the municipal court and for violations of state law returnable to any state court. 
(Code 1977, § 8-9) 
Sec. 30-39. - Magistrates; appointment; powers.
