(d)  Violation of any portion of this article is a misdemeanor for which any police officer may issue a summons or make a custodial arrest. 
(Ord. No. 2001-224, § 1, 7-24-01) 
Secs. 54-69-54-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - AUTHORITY OF CHIEF OF POLICE DISPOSAL OF PROPERTY/FIREARMS 

Sec. 54-91. - Permanent records kept. 
    The Dothan Police Department shall keep a permanent record of each piece of stolen or abandoned property taken or stored including the date of the taking of each piece of property, the place where it was found and taken and a description of the property shall be kept. 
(Ord. No. 2017-294, § 1, 9-19-17) 
Sec. 54-92. - Property shall be stored in a suitable place. 
    The property shall be stored in a suitable place, provided that if the property be perishable it may be sold at once without notice, in which case the proceeds shall be held for a period of six months for the account of the owner and if not called for within that time shall be converted into the general fund of the City of Dothan. 
(Ord. No. 2017-294, § 1, 9-19-17) 
Sec. 54-93. - Property shall be sold at auction. 
    The Chief of Police for the City of Dothan shall sell at public auction nonperishable personal property that has been accumulated and held by the Dothan Police Department for a period of no less than three months. 
(Ord. No. 2017-294, § 1, 9-19-17) 
Sec. 54-94. - Notice of public sale. 
    Notice of such public sale shall be advertised as to the time and location once a week for two successive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation published in Dothan, Alabama. The first day of such publication shall be at least 20 days before the sale. 
(Ord. No. 2017-294, § 1, 9-19-17) 
Sec. 54-95. - Firearms sold only to licensed dealers. 
    Firearms may only be sold to licensed firearms dealers. 
(Ord. No. 2017-294, § 1, 9-19-17) 
Sec. 54-96. - Owner of property may redeem property prior to sale. 
    The owner of any of the property taken up and stored may redeem the same at any time prior to its sale by paying the reasonable expense of storing it and a pro rata of the cost of publication. 
(Ord. No. 2017-294, § 1, 9-19-17) 
Sec. 54-97. - Person making sale shall have right to reject bids. 
    Each article shall be sold separately and records kept of the amount received for each article. The person making the sale shall have the right to reject any and all bids and shall have the right to continue the sale from time to time if there are no bids. 
(Ord. No. 2017-294, § 1, 9-19-17) 
Sec. 54-98. - Balances shall be paid into the general fund. 
    After deducting and paying of all expenses of taking up, storing and selling the property, the balance, if any, shall be paid into the general fund of the City of Dothan. 
(Ord. No. 2017-294, § 1, 9-19-17) 
Chapter 62 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; animals, ch. 10. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 62-1. - State misdemeanor. 
(a)  Any person or corporation committing an offense within the corporate limits of the city, or within the police jurisdiction thereof, which is declared by a law or laws of the state now existing or hereafter enacted to be a misdemeanor, shall be guilty of an offense against the city. 
(b)  Any person or corporation committing an offense within the corporate limits of the city, or within the police jurisdiction thereof, which is declared by laws of the state now existing or hereafter enacted to be a violation, shall be guilty of an offense against the city. 
(c)  Any person or corporation committing, within the corporate limits of the city or within the police jurisdiction thereof, an offense as defined by Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-1-2 of the Alabama Criminal Code, which offense is not declared by laws of the state, now existing or hereafter enacted, to be a felony, misdemeanor or violation, shall be guilty of an offense against the city. 
(d)  Any person found to be in violation of subsections (a), (b) or (c) of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than $1.00 nor more than $500.00, and/or may be imprisoned or sentenced to hard labor for the city for a period not exceeding six months, at the discretion of the court trying the case, unless otherwise provided by subsection (e) of this section. Any corporation found to be in violation of subsections (a), (b) or (c) of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than $1.00 nor more than $500.00, at the discretion of the court trying the case. 
(e)  Any person found to be in violation of Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-191, as amended, shall: 
(1)  Upon first conviction be punished by imprisonment in the county or municipal jail for not more than one year, or by a fine of not less than $500.00 nor more than $2,000.00, or by both a fine and imprisonment. 
(2)  On a second conviction within a five-year period, be punished by a fine of not less than $1,000.00 nor more than $5,000.00 and by imprisonment, which may include hard labor in the county or municipal jail for not more than one year. The sentence shall include a mandatory sentence, which is not subject to suspension or probation, of imprisonment in the county or municipal jail for not less than 48 consecutive hours or community service for not less than 20 days. 
(3)  On a third conviction within a five-year period, be punished by a fine of not less than $2,000.00 nor more than $10,000.00 and by imprisonment, which may include hard labor, in the county or municipal jail for not less than 60 days nor more than one year, to include a minimum of 60 days which shall be served in the county or municipal jail and cannot be probated or suspended. 
(Code 1977, § 9-1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-191(e-g). 
Sec. 62-2. - Convict registration. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Felony means any offense punishable by death or imprisonment in a penitentiary, either state or federal. 
    Resident or residing means any person who remains within the city or its police jurisdiction for a period of more than 24 hours and maintains sleeping quarters anywhere within the city or its police jurisdiction. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-11-180. 
(b)  Time for registering; sworn statement; issuance of cards; change of address; duty to carry card. Registration procedures and practices are as follows: 
(1)  It shall be the duty of every person who has been previously convicted of any felony under the laws of any state or the federal government, and who has not been restored to his civil rights by competent authority, and who resides within the city or its police jurisdiction, to register, within 24 hours after his arrival in the city or its police jurisdiction, in a book of registration to be kept by the chief of police at the city hall. 
(2)  Such person shall make a sworn statement upon blanks to be furnished by the police department stating the offense for which he has been convicted, the time and place of conviction and his address while residing in the city. 
(3)  Upon registration and the filing of the affidavit provided for in this subsection, the chief of police shall give to such person a registration card showing the name and address of such person in the city or its police jurisdiction and the date of registration, which registration card must be signed by the chief of police or one of the police officers. 
(4)  It shall be the duty of any person who has registered as provided in this section who changes his address or place of residence in the city to inform the police of such change within 24 hours after the change has been made, which shall be noted on the records of the chief of police and also on the registration card. 
(5)  It shall be the duty of any person receiving a registration card to carry the card with him on his person at all times while he is within the city or its police jurisdiction, and to exhibit the card to any officer of the city upon request. 
(Code 1977, § 9-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 13A-11-181-13A-11-183. 
(c)  Records. No persons except the chief of police or his assistants, shall have access to or be permitted to examine the registration book or the sworn statement provided for in subsection (b) of this section. 
(Code 1977, §§ 9-2-9-4) 
Sec. 62-3. - False hotel registration. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to write or cause to be written or knowingly permit to be written, in any register in any lodginghouse, hotel or tourist home in the city or in the police jurisdiction of the city, any other or different name or designation than the true name of the person registered therein, or the name by which such person is generally known. 
(Code 1977, § 9-10) 
Sec. 62-4. - Circulars, handbills, other printed matter. 
(a)  Attachments to and clearance around utility poles. In order to provide safe descent by linemen in cases of emergency, it shall be unlawful to attach handbills, posters, placards, advertising materials or any other object or obstruction to or place the same within three feet of any electric, telephone or other utility pole within the corporate limits of the city or the police jurisdiction thereof. 
(b)  Distribution upon public ways. It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute or to employ any person to distribute circulars, pamphlets, placards, advertisements or other printed matter upon the streets or place the same in or on any motor vehicle in the city or the police jurisdiction of the city. Nothing contained in this subsection shall be construed as prohibiting the sale or distribution of newspapers, magazines or other regularly published publications of like character. 
(Code 1977, §§ 11-16, 11-17) 
Sec. 62-5. - Escaping from custody. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City prisoner means a person who has been convicted and sentenced to hard labor for the city for violation of a city ordinance; who is serving hard labor time in the city jail for being in default of the payment of a fine imposed for the violation of any city ordinance; who is serving hard labor time in the city jail for violation of a state law; or who is otherwise confined in the city jail pursuant to an order of court. 
    Custody means the state of being held in keeping whereby one's freedom or liberty is in some manner curtailed. It includes both actual and constructive supervision, and includes a restraint or detention in the city jail, or by any city police officer, and includes a work detail while under the actual or constructive supervision of any city employee to whom the city prisoner was entrusted by the chief of police or his designee. The definition includes the time traveling to and from the city jail or work detail. 
    Escape means its ordinary accepted meaning and connotes an unauthorized voluntary departure from, or substantial severance of, custody. 
    Work detail means a task or job assignment outside the city jail, on public property. Such task or job assignment shall begin and end as determined by the chief of police or his designee, not by any other city employee. 
(b)  Prohibited acts. It shall be unlawful for any city prisoner to escape or run away from custody. 
(c)  Prima facie evidence of escape. For purposes of this section, it shall be prima facie evidence of escape that a city prisoner failed to return to his place of confinement when scheduled to do so on the day of his work detail. 
(Code 1977, § 9-23) 
Secs. 62-6-62-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MINORS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 62-36-62-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CURFEW 

Sec. 62-66. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City means the City of Dothan, Houston County, Alabama, with administrative offices at 126 N. St. Andrews Street, Dothan, Alabama 36303. 
    Minor/Juvenile means any person 17 years of age or younger and not emancipated. 
    Parent means any person having legal custody of a minor: 
(1)  As a natural adoptive; 
(2)  As a legal guardian; 
(3)  As a person who stands in loco parentis; or 
(4)  As a person to whom legal custody has been given by order of court. 
    Street means a way or place, of whatsoever nature, open to the use of the public as a matter of right for purposes of vehicular travel or, in the case of a sidewalk, for pedestrian travel. The term "street" includes the legal right-of-way including, but not limited to, the cartway or traffic lanes, the curb, the sidewalks (whether paved or unpaved), and any grass plots or other grounds found within the legal right-of-way of a street. The term "street" applies irrespective of what it is called or formally named, whether an alley, avenue, court, road or otherwise. 
    Time of night means based upon the prevailing standard of time whether Central Standard Time or Central Daylight Saving Time, generally observed at that hour by the public in the city, and prima facie the time then observed in the city administrative offices and police station. 
(Code 1977, § 9-5) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 62-67. - Penalty for violation of division. 
    Upon a violation of this division for the first time, a parent shall be given a warning citation. A parent, upon further violations, shall be summoned to municipal court and if convicted may be fined up to $500.00 and/or six months in jail. Upon further violations, a minor/juvenile shall be subject to and dealt with under proper procedure in juvenile court pursuant to state law. Each violation of this division shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1977, § 9-7.1) 
Sec. 62-68. - Restrictions enumerated. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any minor 17 years of age or younger to loiter, wander, stroll or play in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other public grounds, public places, public buildings, places of amusement, eating places, vacant lots or any place unsupervised by an adult having the lawful authority to be at such places, between the hours of 10:00 p.m. on any day and 6:00 a.m. of the following day; provided, however, that on Fridays and Saturdays the effective hours are between 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. of the following day; and provided that the provisions of this section shall not apply in the following instances: 
(1)  When a minor is accompanied by his parent or guardian having the lawful care and custody of the minor; 
(2)  When the minor is upon an emergency errand directed by his parent or guardian having the lawful care and custody of such minor; 
(3)  When the minor is returning directly home from a school activity, entertainment, recreational activity or dance; 
(4)  When the minor is going to or returning directly home from lawful employment that makes it necessary to be in the places described in subsection (a)(3) of this section during the prescribed period of time; 
(5)  When the minor is attending or traveling directly to or from an activity involving the exercise of first amendment rights of free speech, freedom of assembly or free exercise of religion; 
(6)  When the minor is in a motor vehicle with parental consent for normal travel in interstate and intrastate travel through the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian, or other person having custody or control of any child 17 years of age or younger to permit, or by insufficient control to allow, such child to be in or upon the public streets or any other places listed in subsection (a) of this section within the city between the hours of 10:00 p.m. on any day and 6:00 a.m. the following day, or on Fridays and Saturdays, between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. the following day except in circumstances set out in subsection (a)(1)-(a)(6) of this section. 
(Code 1977, § 9-6) 
Sec. 62-69. - Police procedures. 
(a)  A police officer of the city, upon finding or having attention called to any minor on the streets in violation of this division, normally shall take the minor to the police station, where a parent shall immediately be notified to come for such minor, whereupon he shall be questioned. This is intended to permit ascertainment, under constitutional safeguards, of relevant facts, and to centralize responsibility in the supervisor there and then on duty for accurate, effective, fair, impartial and uniform enforcement and recording, thus making available experienced supervisory personnel, the best of facilities and access to information and records. In the absence of convincing evidence such as a birth certificate or driver's license, a police officer on the street shall in the first instance use his best judgment in determining age. 
(b)  Police procedures shall constantly be refined in the light of experience and may provide, inter alia, that the police officer may deliver to a parent thereof a minor under appropriate circumstances, for example a minor of tender age near home whose identity and address may readily be ascertained or are known. 
(c)  In any event, such police officer shall, within 24 hours, file a written report with the chief of police, or shall participate to the extent of the information for which he is responsible in the preparation by himself and the supervisor involved in such case, and in the filing of such report within 24 hours. 
(d)  When a parent, immediately called, has come to take charge of the minor, and the appropriate information has been recorded, the minor shall be released to the custody of such parent. If the parent cannot be located, or fails to take charge of the minor, then the minor shall be released to the juvenile authorities, except to the extent that in accordance with police regulations, approved in advance by juvenile authorities, the minor may temporarily be entrusted to a relative, neighbor or other person who will on behalf of a parent assume the responsibility of caring for the minor pending the availability or arrival of a parent. 
(e)  In the case of a first violation by a minor, the chief of police shall, by certified mail, send to a parent written notice of such violation with a warning that any subsequent violation will result in full enforcement of this division, including enforcement of parental responsibility and of applicable penalties. 
(Code 1977, § 9-7) 
Secs. 62-70-62-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NOISE 

Sec. 62-101. - Loud, disturbing or unnecessary; prohibited generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make, create or maintain any unreasonable, loud, disturbing or unnecessary noise within the city or police jurisdiction thereof. Noise of such character, intensity or duration as to be detrimental to life, health, comfort or repose of any individual is prohibited. 
(Code 1977, § 11-19) 
Sec. 62-102. - Enumeration of prohibited acts. 
    The following noises and other noises of the same characteristics, intensity or annoyance shall be prohibited at all times and at all places within the city and police jurisdiction thereof: 
(1)  Horns and signaling devices. The sounding of any horn or signaling device on any automobile, motorcycle, bus or other vehicle on any street or public place of the city except as a danger warning; the creation by means of any such signaling device of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound; the sounding of any such device for an unnecessary and unreasonable period of time; the use of any signaling device except one operated by hand or electricity; the use of any horn, whistle or other device operated by engine exhaust; and the use of any such signaling device when traffic is for any reason held up. 
(2)  Radios, phonographs and other devices for production or reproduction of sound. The following devices for the production or reproduction of sounds are restricted as follows: 
a.  The use or operation of any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such manner as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants or at any time with louder volume than is necessary for convenient hearing for the person of normal hearing who is in the room, vehicle or chamber of which such machine or device is operated and who is a voluntary listener thereto or allowing such use or operation. 
b.  It is hereby declared a nuisance and shall be unlawful to operate or play any radio, phonograph or similar device, whether from a motor vehicle or by a pedestrian, in such a manner as to be plainly audible to any person other than the player or operator of the device at a distance of five feet in the case of a motor vehicle or ten feet in the case of a pedestrian. 
c.  It is hereby declared a nuisance and shall be unlawful to operate or play any radio, television, phonograph, musical instrument or similar device which produces sound, whether from a business or a residence, in such a manner as to be plainly audible to others at a distance of 50 feet to any person in a commercial, residential, multifamily dwelling or public place. 
(3)  Loudspeakers, amplifiers for advertising and other similar machines and devices. The use or operation of any radio, receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, loudspeaker, sound amplifier or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound which is cast upon the public streets for the purpose of commercial advertising or attracting the attention of the public to any building, product, service, merchandise or political candidate, or allowing such use or operation, except as authorized by the board of commissioners. 
(4)  Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling or singing. Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling or singing on the public streets, particularly, between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. or at any time or place so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any office, or in any dwelling, hotel or other type of residence, or of any persons in the vicinity. 
(5)  Animals and birds. The keeping of any animal or bird which by causing frequent or long continued noise shall disturb the comfort or repose of any persons in the vicinity. 
(6)  Steam whistles. The blowing of any steam whistle attached to any stationary boiler except to give notice of the time to begin or stop work, or as a warning of fire or danger, or upon the request of proper city authorities. 
(7)  Exhausts. The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any engine, stationary internal combustion engine or motor vehicle except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom. 
(8)  Defect in vehicle or load. The use of any automobile, motorcycle or vehicle so out of repair, so loaded or in such manner as to create loud and unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling or other noises. 
(9)  Loading, unloading and opening boxes, bales, crates and containers. The creation of a loud and excessive noise in connection with the loading or unloading of any vehicle, or the opening and destruction of bales, boxes, crates and containers on Sundays, Christmas, New Year's or Thanksgiving or before 7:00 a.m. or after 11:00 p.m.; provided, however, that under emergency conditions the city may grant exceptions thereto. 
(10)  Adjacent to schools, courts, churches and hospitals. The creation of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school, institution of learning, church or court while such institution is in use, or adjacent to any hospital, which unreasonably interferes with the workings of such institutions, or which disturbs or unduly annoys patients in the hospital; provided, however, that conspicuous signs are displayed in such streets indicating that the institution is a school, hospital, church or court street. 
(11)  Hawkers, peddlers and vendors. The shouting and crying of peddlers, hawkers and vendors which disturbs the peace and quiet of the neighborhood. 
(12)  Drums or other devices. The use of any drum or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention by creation of noise to any performance, show or sale. 
(13)  Firearms and fireworks. The explosion of firecrackers, skyrockets, Roman candles, pinwheels or any other form of fireworks or the unnecessary shooting of any firearms, except as specifically authorized by law or the proper official. 
(14)  Transportation of metal rails, pillars and columns. The transportation of rails, pillars or columns of iron, steel or other material, over and along the streets and other public places upon carts, drays, cars, trucks or in any other manner so loaded as to cause loud noises or as to disturb the peace and quiet of such streets or other public places. 
(15)  Operation of public transportation buses. The causing, permitting or continuing of any excessive, unnecessary and avoidable noise in the operation of a public transportation bus. 
(16)  Piledrivers, hammers and similar appliances. The operation of any piledriver, steam shovel, pneumatic hammer, derrick, steam or electric hoist or other appliance, the use of which is attended by loud or unusual noise, except on written permission of the city prescribing the locality where the hours during which such operation is permissible. 
(17)  Blowers. The operation of any noise-creating blower or power fan, or any internal combustion engine, the operation of which causes noise due to the explosion of operating gases or fluids, unless the noise from such blower or fan is muffled and such engine is equipped with a muffler device sufficient to deaden such noise. 
(18)  Air conditioning units. Self-contained, one-room air conditioning units, up to one-ton capacity attached to the outside walls or windows of buildings within the city, and operated for the comfort of the occupants of such buildings, shall be maintained in good mechanical condition. Air conditioning units of more than one-ton capacity may not be operated within the city except where remote compressors are housed in soundproof rooms, or where attached or immediately adjoining compressors are sound treated or baffled, and cooling coil and condensation water is disposed of, as prescribed by the city. 
(Code 1977, § 11-20) 
Sec. 62-103. - Operation of automobiles and light delivery vehicles. 
    The requirements of sections 62-101 and 62-102 shall not be construed to prevent the operation of automobiles or light delivery vehicles at any time; provided, however, that such motor vehicles shall not have any attachment thereon for creating unnecessary noise, shall at all times be properly muffled and shall be so operated as to create the least possible noise or nuisance. 
(Code 1977, § 11-21) 
Sec. 62-104. - City may waive requirements of sections 62-101 and 62-102. 
    The city shall have the right to waive any or all of the requirements of sections 62-101 and 62-102 in cases of emergency where the welfare of persons or property may be jeopardized by their strict enforcement or on such special occasions as the commission may determine. The following exceptions also apply: 
(1)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the ringing of bells or chimes by churches within the city. 
(2)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit any noises or sounds produced by radios, sirens or other equipment attached to, or being operated by, any police, fire, rescue or other emergency vehicles or personnel. 
(3)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the conducting of live remote broadcasts by duly licensed radio stations upon business premises, at the request of the owner of the business. Such live remote broadcasts shall be limited to daylight hours only. 
(Code 1977, § 11-22) 
Sec. 62-105. - Penalty for violation of article. 
(a)  Violations of sections 62-101 and 62-102 shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $200.00 on a first offense. Subsequent or repeated violations shall subject the violator to arrest and shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00 and/or six months in the municipal jail. 
(b)  The police department is authorized to issue a citation for a first offense. Subsequent and repeated violations will result in arrest. 
(c)  Each violation shall be a separate offense. 
(Code 1977, § 11-22.1) 
Secs. 62-106-62-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC HEALTH AND MORALS 

Sec. 62-136. - Prostitution. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person in the city or in its police jurisdiction to: 
(1)  Engage in prostitution. 
(2)  Aid or abet prostitution, or frequent the company of prostitutes. 
(3)  Procure or solicit for purposes of prostitution. 
(4)  Keep or set up a house of ill fame, brothel or bawdy house. 
(5)  Receive any person for purposes of lewdness, assignation or prostitution into any vehicle, conveyance, place, structure or building. 
(6)  Permit any person to remain for the purpose of lewdness, assignation or prostitution in any vehicle, conveyance, place, structure or building. 
(7)  Lease or rent, or contract to lease or rent, any vehicle, conveyance, place, structure or building or part thereof, knowingly or with good reason to know that it is intended to be used for any of the purposes prohibited in this section. 
(8)  Attempt to do any of the acts prohibited by this section. 
(9)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or manager of any hotel, boardinghouse, lodginghouse, motel or any other place wherein rooms are for hire, to employ any person who has been convicted under this section. 
(b)  This section shall not be construed to encompass Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 13A-12-111, 13A-12-112. 
(c)  In addition to other penalties, the violation of this section shall be cause for revocation of the city privilege license of the person guilty of such violation. 
(Code 1977, § 9-14) 
State Law reference- Authority to control, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-113. 
Sec. 62-137. - Volatile and noxious substances. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Noxious substance means any substance that produces an offensive odor; lacrimation; irritation of the skin, mucous membranes, or eyes; difficulty in breathing, damage to any part of the human body, damage to any surface or object when applied, any corrosive substance, any liquid substance containing oleoresin capsicum or similar substance; any substance commonly known as tear gas, mace, CS, CN, smoke grenade or smoke device, stink bomb, or similar device or substance, whether in crystal, aerosol, liquid or other form; and any incendiary device, grenade or other device that may dispense any of the enumerated substances. 
    Volatile substance means any substance that has the capability of giving off vapors or fumes, or of being inhaled, that upon being inhaled may produce symptoms of intoxication, dizziness, euphoria, paralysis, or other symptoms that impair the person to a degree that they are a danger to themselves or another person. This definition does not apply to the legitimate utilization of licensed anesthesia for medical or dental purposes under the supervision of a physician or dentist. Volatile substances include, but are not limited to: 
(1)  Model glue; 
(2)  Gasoline, kerosene, other hydrocarbon liquids; 
(3)  Acetone; 
(4)  Amylacetate; 
(5)  Benzene; 
(6)  Butyl acetate, butyl alcohol; 
(7)  Carbon tetrachloride; 
(8)  Chloroform; 
(9)  Cyclohexanone; 
(10)  Ethanol and ethane; 
(11)  Ethyl acetate; 
(12)  Hexane; 
(13)  Isopropyl alcohol; 
(14)  Methyl acetate; 
(15)  Methyl ethyl ketone; 
(16)  Methyl isobutyl ketone; 
(17)  Toluol or toluene; 
(18)  Trichloroethylene; 
(19)  Xyol or xylene; 
(20)  Petroleum derivatives; 
(21)  Aerosol sprays of any type, including paints; 
(22)  Butane, ethane; 
(23)  Fluorocarbons; 
(24)  Nitrous oxide; and 
(25)  Any other solvent, gas, material, substance, chemical or combination that has the property of being inhaled, producing vapors or fumes that may produce the effects described in this definition, including any product upon which the container carries a warning therefor. 
(b)  Use of volatile substances. It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally inhale any volatile substances for the purpose of producing intoxication, impairment or any of the symptoms described in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  Having symptoms of volatile substance impairment. It shall be unlawful for any person to have any of the symptoms described in subsection (a) of this section from inhaling any of the volatile substances. A person having the symptoms of impairment, or any of the symptoms or conditions described in subsection (a) of this section, present with any of the volatile substances is sufficient for a violation of this section. 
(d)  Possession of volatile substances. It shall be unlawful for any person to possess any of the volatile substances with the intent of violating any part of this section. Possession of any of the volatile substances with the commonly used paraphernalia to inhale such substances is sufficient to prove intent. 
(e)  Furnishing of volatile substances to minors. It shall be unlawful for any person to furnish, sell, give or otherwise provide to any minor model glue, unless such minor is accompanied by a parent or guardian or has written consent to purchase such model glue. No minor may possess any model glue or any of the volatile substances for any purpose without permission of their parents or guardian. 
(f)  Possession by and sales to minors of noxious substances. It shall be unlawful for any minor to possess any noxious substance and illegal for any person to sell, provide, give or otherwise furnish any minor a noxious substance. 
(g)  Possession of and intent to use noxious substances. It shall be unlawful for any person to possess any noxious substance with the intent to use such noxious substance unlawfully. Possession of a noxious substance within a gathering of persons, near such a gathering, or within a structure or vehicle is sufficient to prove intent. 
(h)  Possession of noxious substances prohibited generally; exceptions. It shall be unlawful for any person, other than school officials or law enforcement officers, to possess any noxious substance on school grounds or within school buildings, stadium grounds, school buses, school property, or school parking lot, or within any vehicle located on or in such areas. 
(i)  Possession of noxious substances on city property. It shall be unlawful for any person to possess any noxious substance within any city-owned building, city-owned property, city parking lot, civic center, recreation facility, city park or other city facility, or within any vehicle located on or within such areas. 
(j)  Application of section to enforcement officials and employees. No portion of this section shall apply to law enforcement officers or other authorized city employees who may utilize such substances as part of their job tasks. 
(k)  Penalty for violation of section. Violation of any portion of this section is punishable as specified in section 1-4. 
(Code 1977, §§ 9-38-9-45) 
Secs. 62-138-62-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC ORDER 

Sec. 62-171. - Weapons; carrying and discharging firearms or air gun. 
(a)  No person shall carry a pistol which uses a powder or air propellant on or about his person, except on his own real property, in his own abode or fixed place of business, without a license therefor, or except as provided for under Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-11-52. 
(b)  No person shall hunt any wild game with a firearm within a distance of 100 yards of any public street, road, highway, residence or place of business. 
(c)  No person shall discharge a firearm or gun which uses a powder or air propellant closer than 100 yards of any residence, except for protection of his property and members of his household in and about which he shall be responsible for damage, injury or endangering the lives and property of others. 
(Code 1977, § 9-12) 
Sec. 62-172. - Assaulting or harassing a public safety officer, judicial official, elected official, department head or city manager. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Public safety officer means any peace officer; any city firefighter, fire medic, jail security officer, traffic or parking enforcement officer, public safety dispatcher, revenue officer, fire official or reserve police officer; any permitted EMT or other employee of a licensed ambulance service within the city; any city magistrate, court clerk, judge, city attorney, city prosecutor, assistant city attorney, mayor and city commissioners, city manager, and city department heads. 
(b)  Assault or harassment by physical contact a misdemeanor. Any person who assaults, attempts to assault, harasses by physical contact, menaces with any object or weapon, or places any public safety officer, or the officials described in subsection (a) of this section, in danger by their negligence or reckless actions, during the performance of their duties or as a result of their position or job, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(c)  Assault or harassment by telephone, mail, electronic or other means a misdemeanor. It shall be unlawful for any person to communicate with, call by telephone, communicate with electronically or in writing, to verbally harass or annoy, any public safety officer, or above enumerated officials, during the performance of their duties, or as a result of their position or job. Such person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(d)  Violators of section to be fined and jailed. Any person found guilty of violating any part of this section shall receive a minimum fine of $250.00 and a minimum jail sentence of 30 days. Neither the fine nor sentence shall be suspended. 
Sec. 62-173. - Police service animals. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    Handler means a law enforcement officer who is especially trained, and uses a police service animal as part of their job duties. 
    Police service animal means any animal used by law enforcement. 
(b)  Misdemeanor. It is a misdemeanor for any person to intentionally or negligently: 
(1)  Cause or attempt to cause injury to a police service animal; 
(2)  Engage in conduct likely to produce or cause bodily injury to a police service animal; 
(3)  Lay out, place, or administer any poison, trap, substance or object which is likely to produce bodily injury to a police service animal; 
(4)  Strike, hit, torment, or otherwise harass or assault a police service animal; 
(5)  Throw any object or substance at, toward or in the path of a police service animal; 
(6)  Interfere with or obstruct a police service animal, or interfere with the handler in any manner to inhibit, restrict or deprive the handler of control of the police service animal; 
(7)  Releases a police service animal from its area of control, such as a vehicle, kennel, or pen, or trespass in that area; 
(8)  Places any food, object, or substance into a police service animal's area of control without permission of the handler. 
(9)  Offer or agree with one or more persons to engage in or cause the performance of an act, which constitutes a violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 98-330, § 1, 11-10-98) 
Secs. 62-174-62-189. - Reserved. 
Article VI. - Extended Magistrates' Fine Schedule 

Sec. 62-190. - Fine schedule adopted. 
    The extended magistrates' fine schedule is hereby adopted in whole as provided for in the Code of Alabaman, Section 23A, Rules of Alabama Supreme Court, Rule 20(c), of the Alabama Rules of Judicial Administration (ARJA) and the same may be changed upon amendments by the state. 
(Ord. No. 2003-199, § 1, 7-22-03) 
Chapter 70 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; cemeteries, ch. 22; subdivisions, ch. 90; zoning, ch. 114. 
State Law reference- Planning, zoning and subdivisions generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 70-1-70-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION 

Sec. 70-31. - Created; members; appointment; terms; service without compensation. 
(a)  Pursuant to and under the authority contained in Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-14, there is hereby adopted an alternate structure for the planning commission of the city, which was created pursuant to and under the authority of Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-3. 
(b)  The commission shall consist of nine members: eight regular members appointed by the commission and representing as equally as possible the several districts, wards or other areas of the municipality, such representation to be determined by the commission, and one regular member to be appointed by the mayor. 
(c)  The regular members of the planning commission shall elect a chairman and a vice-chairman, both of whom shall be regular members, and a secretary which need not be a member of the planning commission. 
(d)  The city commission shall appoint four supernumerary members to the planning commission, and the mayor shall appoint one supernumerary member to the planning commission. 
(e)  Supernumerary members shall serve at the call of the chairman, only in the absence of regular members or in the event that one or more regular members excuse themselves from deliberation on a particular item being considered by the planning commission. While so serving, supernumerary members shall have and exercise the power and authority of regular members. 
(f)  The terms of the regular members and supernumerary members appointed by the commission shall be four years or until their successors take office. Any regular member or supernumerary member may be reappointed. 
(g)  After the public hearing, the commission, in the case of regular or supernumerary members appointed by it, or the mayor, in the case of the regular or the supernumerary member appointed by him or a previous mayor, may remove a regular or supernumerary member for reason of inefficiency, neglect of duty, malfeasance in office or continued failure to attend meetings. The commission or mayor, as the case may be, shall file a written statement of reasons for removal. 
(h)  Vacancies occurring other than through expiration of term shall be filled for the duration of the unexpired term by the mayor in the case of the regular member and supernumerary member appointed by him or a previous mayor; and by the commission in the case of the regular members and supernumerary members appointed by it. 
(i)  The city engineer of the city shall be an ex officio member of the planning commission but shall have no voting privileges. 
(j)  All regular members and supernumerary members shall serve as such without compensation, and shall hold no other municipal office. 
(Code 1977, § 2-7) 
Sec. 70-32. - Functions; duties; authority as prescribed by law. 
    Unless specified otherwise in Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-14, the duties, powers, responsibilities and procedures of the planning commission shall be as provided for in tit. 11, ch. 52, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-82-1 et seq. 
(Code 1977, § 2-8) 
Chapter 74 - RAILROADS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86. 
State Law reference- Authority regarding railroads generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-81. 

Sec. 74-1. - Construction and repair of sidewalks, streets, sewers, culverts and approaches-Required. 
(a)  It is the duty of each railroad company operating a railroad into or through the city to build and keep in repair all sidewalk or street crossings over or along its line of railway and all approaches to such crossings corresponding to the streets and sidewalks of adjacent city property. Railroad companies shall also build and keep in repair all bridges along or across its line and all approaches thereto. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of each railroad company operating a line of railway into or through the city to build and maintain sewers and culverts along and under its railroad or right-of-way of sufficient capacity to carry off the surface waters flowing to its railroad or right-of-way, and to keep the sewers and culverts in repair and free from obstruction to water flowing through such sewers and culverts. 
(Code 1977, § 16-1) 
Sec. 74-2. - Same-Noncompliance; notice; penalty. 
    When any railroad company fails to comply with section 74-1 it shall be the duty of the city attorney to give such railroad company notice by serving a written notice on any agent of such company to build such crossings or bridges or approaches thereto, or to make repairs, as the case may be; and, after notice served such company, shall be liable to a fine as provided in section 1-4 for each day that it shall be in default, which penalty may be recovered by suit. 
(Code 1977, § 16-2) 
Sec. 74-3. - Obstructing streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating a railroad into or through the city to stop its trains, cars or locomotives on any street in the city or otherwise obstruct any street by stopping a train, car or locomotive on any railroad, so that free use of any person traveling over and along such street would be impeded and the streets obstructed for more than five minutes. 
(Code 1977, § 16-3) 
Sec. 74-4. - Kicking; making a flying switch. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to kick or make a flying switch of railroad cars, loaded or empty, on or across the streets or public ways of the city. Each time that a railroad car, empty or loaded, is so kicked, or a flying switch made of any such car over or across the streets or public ways of the city, it shall constitute a separate offense; provided, however, that the yardmaster or conductor or any other employee of the railroad company responsible shall be deemed to be the guilty party within the meaning of this section. 
(Code 1977, § 16-4) 
Chapter 82 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, adopted Apr. 3, 2007, amended Ch. 82 in its entirety, in effect deleting Ch. 82 as being superseded and enacting a new Ch. 82 to read as set out herein. Former Ch. 82 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1977, §§ 11-14, 11-15, 20-71-20-73, 20-75, 20-76. 
Cross reference- Utilities, Ch. 102. 
State Law reference- Authority regarding garbage generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-135. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 82-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivatives shall have the meanings given in this section: 
    Ashes. Ashes refers to all residue resulting from the combustion of coal, coke, wood or any other material or substances in domestic stoves, furnaces, boilers or fireplaces. 
    Authorized residential containers. Only containers furnished by the city will be emptied by the city. Any exceptions must be made by the public works director. 
    Building material. Building material refers to any material such as lumber, brick, block, carpet, stone, plaster, concrete, asphalt, roofing shingles, gutters, flooring, carpeting or other substances accumulated as the result of repairs, remodeling, or additions to existing buildings or structures, or as the result of construction or demolition of buildings or structures or any part thereof. 
    Bulky refuse. Solid household or residential refuse weighing more than 50 pounds and/or having a volume greater than four cubic feet, including, but not limited to, appliances such as stoves, refrigerators, washing machines, dryers and furniture. 
    Establishment. An establishment shall include all structures, businesses, and/or units located on one common ground. The public works director shall determine the appropriateness of such definition on a case-by-case basis. 
    Garbage. Garbage refers to all putrescible animal and vegetable waste, liquid or other waste resulting from the handling, processing, preparation, cooking and consumption of food, and all cans, bottles or other containers originally used for foodstuffs. 
    Garden refuse. All accumulations of plants, stems, roots, vegetables and fruits remaining after harvest are referred to as garden refuse. 
    Hazardous refuse. Any chemical, compound, mixture, substance or article, which may constitute a hazard to health or may cause damage to property by reason of being explosive, flammable, poisonous, corrosive, unstable, irritating, radioactive or otherwise harmful is referred to as hazardous refuse. 
    Industrial waste. Industrial waste refers to all wastes peculiar to industrial, manufacturing or processing plants. 
    Landscape debris. Any material such as dirt, soil, rock, mulch, timbers, cross ties, concrete blocks, pavers or other substances accumulated as a result of landscaping activity is referred to as landscape debris. 
    Litter. Rubbish, refuse, waste material, garbage, dead animals or fowl, offal, plastic, paper, glass, cans, bottles, trash, scrap metal, debris, or any foreign substance of whatever kind or description, and whether or not it is of value. Any agricultural product in its natural state that is unintentionally deposited on a public road, highway, street or right-of-way shall not be deemed litter for purposes of this section. 
    Nonresidential establishment. A nonresidential establishment is any establishment except those defined under "residential establishment." Nonresidential establishments shall be divided into the following categories: 
(1)  Commercial. Restaurants, motels, hotels, private cemeteries, retail and wholesale business establishments and offices where a product is not manufactured; 
(2)  Educational facilities. All public schools and universities; 
(3)  Fraternal, social and professional clubs and organizations. Lodges, social clubs, labor unions, etc; 
(4)  Governmental. Local, state and federal governmental agencies; 
(5)  Industrial. All manufacturing and fabricating businesses; 
(6)  Multiple-family structures. Any apartment complex with four or more units or any type of condominium, any mobile home park with four or more units, and public housing; 
(7)  Private educational facilities. All nonpublic schools, colleges and universities; 
(9)  Professional. All hospitals, doctors' offices, animal hospitals, clinics, etc; and 
(10)  Religious. All churches, synagogues and church-operated or affiliated agencies. 
    Park. A park is any reservation, playground, recreation center or any other public area in the city, owned or used by the city, and devoted to active or passive recreation. 
    Private premises. Any dwelling, house, building or other structure, designed or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule, or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building, or other structure. 
    Producer. The producer is either the person responsible for the ashes, garbage, refuse, trash, industrial waste and any other waste material or the occupant of the place or building in which such is produced or in which the person responsible for such has a place of business or residence. 
    Public place. Public places refer to any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other public ways and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds and buildings. 
    Refuse. Refuse refers to all perishable and nonperishable solid wastes (except body wastes) including garbage, trash, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, cuttings and bulky refuse. 
    Residential establishments. Residential establishments refer to single or multiple-family dwelling units up to and including apartment complexes, condominiums or trailer parks of three or less units. 
    Sanitary refuse disposal site. Any site wherein solid waste is properly disposed of, including but not limited to landfills, public incinerator plants, publicly operated convenience centers, publicly operated transfer station sites, publicly operated recycling centers, and brush burner sites operated by the city are referred to as sanitary refuse disposal sites. 
    Trash. Trash is the non-putrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes such as paper, boxes, cloth, wrappings, crates, grass clippings, cuttings, leaves, glass and similar material. It shall not include bulky refuse, meaning stoves, refrigerators, water tanks, washing machines, furniture, bedding, furnaces or similar bulky material weighing more than 50 pounds and/or having a volume greater than 30 gallons. Trash shall be divided into three categories: 
(1)  Household trash. Waste accumulations of paper, sweepings, dust, rags, bottles, cans or other matter of any kind, other than garbage, which is usually attendant to housekeeping; 
(2)  Yard trash. Cuttings, leaves, grass clippings, garden refuse, etc., resulting from normal maintenance and care of landscaped, manicured grounds and lawns, but does not include cuttings and leaves from that portion of grounds that have been left in its natural state without normal maintenance; and 
(3)  Cuttings. Cuttings refer to all tree limbs, trimmings, shrubbery, etc. 
    Vacant property. Vacant property refers to all parcels of land without any permanent dwelling or business structure or any parcels of land with a dwelling or business structure that have remained vacant for a period of six months without routine maintenance to that yard and grounds. This shall also include portions of grounds and/or yards left in their natural state. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-2-07) 
Sec. 82-2. - Purpose. 
    This section is determined and declared to be a sanitary measure for the protection and promotion of the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of Dothan. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-2-07) 
Sec. 82-3. - Rules and regulations. 
    The public works director may make necessary or desirable rules and regulations that are not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter in order to aid in its administration and in order to ensure compliance and enforcement. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-2-07) 
Secs. 82-4-82-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RESIDENTIAL COLLECTION 

Sec. 82-19. - Containerized refuse, collection frequency, placement, etc. 
(a)  Refuse such as ashes, garbage, household trash, and containerized "yard trash" shall be collected from each residential establishment once a week by the city. No hazardous refuse will be collected by the city. In the event of severe weather or other unforeseen disaster, collection may be suspended until the following week. The public works director shall prepare schedules for regular collection of refuse. 
(b)  Residential collection shall be made from curbside and approved city alleys at the exact location as determined by the public works director. Where there is no approved alley or curbside, carts shall be located as indicated by the public works director. Alley collection service may be denied to residential establishments by the public works director, if such alley is not easily accessible to the city garbage truck. 
(c)  If two or more residential establishments are located on a private road and not within a reasonable distance of a public street or alley, as determined by the public works director, collection of refuse stored in authorized residential carts may be made along the private road only if the owner(s) provides written approval for city collection trucks to travel on the private road. The city shall not be liable for any damages done to the private road as a result of normal use for ingress and egress. If approval is not granted by all owners along private drive, said owners must place containers along a public street at a location determined by the public works director. 
(d)  Residential carts shall be placed at the appropriate location as described in subsection (b) above no later than 6:00 a.m. on the day of collection and removed from curbside by 6:00 a.m. the day after collection has occurred. Carts shall be stored inconspicuously behind the front building line at the residence as determined by the public works director. 
(Ord. No. 2006-O-002, § 1, 9-5-06) 
Sec. 82-20. - Yard trash, cuttings and bulky refuse, collection, frequency, placement, etc. 
(a)  Yard trash piles, cuttings piles, and bulky refuse shall be collected from each residential establishment not more than once a week by the city and on a schedule developed by the public works director. 
(b)  Yard trash piles, cuttings piles and bulky refuse collection shall be made from curbside only. Where there is no curb, yard trash and bulk refuse shall be located as indicated by the public works director. 
(c)  Collection of yard trash piles during the leaf season shall be scheduled for each residential establishment twice per month and more frequently if possible. 
(d)  Yard trash piles of pine straw, leaves and grass clippings and garden refuse shall be piled free of limbs, rocks, boards and other hard, bulky materials that may be injurious to, or noncompatible with, mechanical pickup equipment. 
(e)  Cuttings, piles of brush, limbs and shrubbery shall be stored in neat piles separate from grass cuttings, leaves and pine straw. Each tree and shrubbery branch and limb shall be cut in lengths of not more than five feet and shall not be more than eight inches in diameter. 
(f)  Certain bulky refuse items, such as appliances, stoves, refrigerators, water tanks, washing machines, dryers, furniture, mattresses, bedsprings, and air conditioners shall be collected by the city when placed curbside on the scheduled trash collection day. 
(g)  Residents with empty moving boxes can be accommodated by contacting environmental services. 
(h)  Trash or any other refuse not stored and placed as provided in articles II and III shall be removed from the premises by the producer or at his expense. The following items of refuse shall also be removed by the owner and/or producer or at his expense: 
(1)  Building material (from other than minor repairs by the owner as determined by the public works director) as defined in article I, whether generated by a contractor, the owner, or any other person; 
(2)  Any refuse not resulting from the normal and routine maintenance of yard, grounds and residences, such as refuse removed from property after the owner was ordered to remove such refuse by any authorized official; 
(3)  Automobile, truck, tractor, and other vehicle tires and any other motor vehicle parts shall be disposed of by the owner or producer; 
(4)  Any trash pushed or pulled into piles by mechanical means shall be disposed of by the owner or producer; 
(5)  Any trash or landscape debris resulting from work performed by contractors or any other person for economic gain, whether such gain is in the form of cash or barter, shall be removed by the owner, occupant, or producer except normal and routine yard trash generated by "yard-workers" shall be collected in accordance with articles II and III. "Yard-workers" as used herein shall mean persons hired by citizens to perform routine lawn maintenance on a repetitive basis and does not include persons hired to do one-time tasks; 
(6)  Any other trash or refuse, except certain household items and appliances defined in subsection (4) of this section, weighing in excess of 50 pounds or having a volume of more than 35 gallons shall be removed by the producer; 
(7)  Any trees or limbs in excess of eight inches in diameter and associated stumps; 
(8)  Any trees, tree trunks, tree tops, tree limbs, stumps or any other tree part thereof resulting from cutting or any other work performed by contractors or any other person for economic gain, whether such gain is in the form of cash or barter, shall be removed by the owner, occupant or producer; and 
(9)  Any hazardous refuse. 
(i)  Refuse collection from vacant property located in residential areas will be limited to debris resulting from cleaning such property. "Cleaning" is defined as the removal of brush, leaves, litter, and other refuse already lying on the ground. It also includes grass cuttings and small volumes of vines appropriately cut and stacked. Refuse resulting from the clearing of vacant property shall be removed by the owner or at their expense. "Clearing" is defined as the cutting or pruning of trees, grubbing, clearing of fence rows, demolition of structures, or grading and excavation of the property. 
(j)  The placing of any trash, refuse, bulk items, etc., in public streets, gutters, or over storm drains is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-2-07) 
Sec. 82-21. - Private property. 
    The city shall not be liable for damage done to private streets, driveways, parking lots, utility wires and connections, or other properties, resulting from normal use for ingress and egress to collect refuse, unless caused by negligence on the part of the city or its employees. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Secs. 82-22-82-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NONRESIDENTIAL COLLECTION 

Sec. 82-36. - Garbage and trash collection; frequency, placement, etc. 
(a)  Refuse from nonresidential establishments will not be collected by the city and shall be removed by the owner or producer unless otherwise approved by the city manager. 
(b)  Tenants, lessees, occupants, or owners of nonresidential establishments shall provide a safe and convenient entrance to and through the premises for the purpose of collecting refuse. The city shall not be liable for damage done to private streets, driveways, parking lots, utility wires and connections, or other properties, resulting from normal use for ingress and egress to collect refuse, unless caused by negligence on the part of the city or its employees. 
(c)  The public works director shall determine the method of solid waste collection for each nonresidential establishment. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Sec. 82-37. - Hazardous refuse. 
    No hazardous refuse shall be placed in any receptacle, container, or unit used for refuse collection by the city. The collection and disposal of such refuse shall be the responsibility of the owner, lessee, occupant, or producer. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Secs. 82-38-82-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - AUTOMATED COLLECTION PROGRAM 

Sec. 82-51. - Providing of rollout refuse cart. 
(a)  One rollout refuse cart will be provided by the city at no cost to the following establishments: 
(1)  Single-family residence; and 
(2)  Each unit of any multi-family structure as approved by the public works director. 
(b)  An additional cart may be obtained for a one-time fee of $50.00. 
(c)  The city will service no more than two authorized carts per residence. A third cart will be available upon approval of the public works director. 
(d)  All carts shall remain the property of the city and shall stay at the residence when the resident moves. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to borrow, steal, damage or otherwise remove any roll-out cart from use in the refuse collection program. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Sec. 82-52. - Location of rollout refuse cart, placement time. 
(a)  The public works director will designate the exact location of each cart to be collected. Carts must be located no greater than three feet from edge of pavement or gutter unless specified otherwise. Carts shall not be placed in the street or gutter. 
(b)  Carts must be three feet from stationary objects such as mailboxes and utility poles. Carts shall not be located under any overhead obstacles, such as utility lines and canopies. 
(c)  Carts not placed in a manner as directed by the public works director, such as the direction of container opening, location, etc., shall not be collected. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Sec. 82-53. - Contents of rollout refuse cart. 
(a)  Cart must not contain hot ashes, liquids, paints, tires, hospital waste, animal carcass or parts, household hazardous waste, or automobile parts. 
(b)  All animal waste must be double bagged prior to placing it in the cart. 
(c)  Total weight of cart and contents shall not exceed 250 pounds. 
(d)  Lid of cart must be in fully closed position to ensure collection. 
(e)  Loose garbage must be bagged before putting in cart to reduce wind-blown litter and ensure the cart is kept clean. 
(f)  Carts may be used for leaves, pine straw, cuttings, prunings, and grass. It is recommended that these items be bagged. 
(g)  All cardboard boxes, cartons, and crates shall be completely collapsed prior to being deposited in cart. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Sec. 82-54. - Collection of rollout refuse cart. 
(a)  Only those carts provided or approved by the city will be collected. 
(b)  Any refuse placed outside the cart will not be collected except for the first scheduled collection day following Christmas day. 
(c)  Carts will not be collected on regular collection day due to: 
(1)  Not being out at times of collection; 
(2)  Improper location; 
(3)  Not facing street properly; 
(4)  Overloaded; 
(5)  Unacceptable contents; 
(6)  Contents lodged or frozen in cart; or 
(7)  As otherwise determined by the public works director. 
(d)  Notification will be given to the residential producer of the reason his or her refuse was not collected. A notice will be left at the residence specifying which requirement(s) in subparagraph three were not met. 
(e)  It is the producer's responsibility to remove and dispose of any unacceptable refuse in an approved manner. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Sec. 82-55. - Replacement of carts. 
(a)  Carts that are assigned to individual establishments remain the property of the city. Carts removed from such establishments will be considered stolen and such will be appropriately processed through applicable courts of law. 
(b)  Any cart that is lost, stolen, or damaged by the user shall be replaced by that user at his or her cost of $50.00 each. Repair or replacement of city carts due to normal wear and tear shall be by the city. If the cart is lost or stolen, the customer should contact both environmental services and the police department. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Secs. 82-56-82-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CONTAINERS 

Sec. 82-71. - Required; premises kept clean. 
(a)  All persons within the city are required to keep their premises in a clean and sanitary condition, free from the accumulation of refuse, except when stored as provided in this chapter. 
(b)  Every person in possession, charge or control of any premises of a residential establishment and the owner, manager or custodian of any nonresidential establishment where garbage or trash is accumulated, shall keep or cause to be kept at all times containers for the deposit of garbage and trash generated on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Sec. 82-72. - Unsatisfactory rollout carts. 
    Rollout carts used for the deposit of garbage or household trash shall be in such good condition that collection thereof shall not injure the person collecting the contents nor be unsuitable for the healthful and sanitary storage of refuse substances. The city is hereby authorized to confiscate or to remove unsatisfactory carts as determined by the public works director from the premises of residential establishments that do not comply with the requirements of this article; provided, however, that the owners, or their agents or lessees, of such carts shall be duly notified of such impending action by five days' notice in writing delivered to the premises on which the unsatisfactory cart is located or affixed to such cart deemed to be unsatisfactory. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Sec. 82-73. - Proximity of other personal effects. 
    Garbage and trash shall not be stored in close proximity to other personal effects, which are not desired to be collected, but shall be reasonably separated in order that the collector can clearly distinguish between what is to be collected and what is not to be collected. Personal effects stored or placed within three feet of a cart or pile of trash shall be presumed to be garbage or trash and collected accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Sec. 82-74. - Residential rollout carts; storage. 
    Lids or covers of authorized residential rollout carts shall be kept tightly closed and watertight at all times other than when refuse is being deposited therein or removed there from. Refuse shall be stored for collection in the following manner: 
(1)  Ashes, garbage and household trash shall be stored in authorized residential rollout carts. Bulky refuse such as furniture, appliances, and yard trash shall also be separated from garbage and placed for collection as provided in articles II and III; and 
(2)  Grass clippings, leaves and pine straw may be placed, either bagged or unbagged, in the city collection cart so long as the weight of such loaded cart does not exceed 250 pounds in weight. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Secs. 82-75-82-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SANITARY REFUSE DISPOSAL SITES AND FEES 

Sec. 82-91. - Designation. 
    The city manager may select and designate, subject to approval of the board of commissioners, suitable and proper sites or locations for sanitary refuse disposal sites for the city. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Sec. 82-92. - City use. 
    Sanitary refuse disposal sites selected, designated and approved shall be used by such persons or other entities as is expressly permitted by the public works director. When it is advantageous to the city and where a shorter haul can be made than to a normal disposal site, waste dirt, straw and leaves may be deposited on private premises where requested and consented to in writing by the resident or owner of the property. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Sec. 82-93. - Days and hours of operation. 
    Any dumping of refuse in sanitary refuse disposal sites by individuals or private haulers shall be done at such times as may be designated by the public works director. Such dumping shall be subject to the direction and control of, and at the specific places designated by, the attendant in charge at such sanitary refuse disposal sites. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Sec. 82-94. - Material disposal control, fees, rates. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of refuse, not suitable for the applicable disposal site as determined by the board of commissioners. All federal and state rules and regulations concerning hazardous and special waste disposal processes shall be followed. Disposal fees, rates, and credits, if any, at the applicable disposal site(s), including transfer station sites and city operated recycling centers, shall be established by resolution of the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Sec. 82-95. - Schedule of fees, rates, credits, etc., for disposal. 
(a)  The following fees shall be paid to the city for refuse, including garbage, trash, debris, etc. delivered to the city landfill for disposal: 
(1)  Nonbusiness pickups/cars with refuse generated within the corporate limits of the city, no charge; 
(2)  Inside the county, commercial and business, and nonbusiness pickups/cars; $38.00 per ton; and 
(3)  Outside the county, excluding that area located in other counties which are a part of the corporate limits of the city, commercial, business, and residential; $120.00 per ton. 
(b)  The fees in subsection (a) of this section are subject to change, by ordinance of the board of commissioners. 
(c)  The public works director shall have the right to waive any landfill fees in connection with public works projects within the city limits. 
(d)  Fees for the delivery of refuse by any person or business without an established account shall be paid at the time of delivery. For all other deliveries, statements shall be billed to the person or business making said delivery at the close of each calendar month. Such statements shall be paid within two weeks of the billing date. Failure to pay account will terminate landfill access. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-3-07; Ord. No. 2008-307, § 1, 10-21-08) 
Sec. 82-96. - Service charge for the collection, hauling and disposing of refuse. 
(a)  Beginning on the 1st day of March 2013, and continuing monthly thereafter a fee of $14.75 shall be paid to the city by every residential customer for the collection, hauling and disposing of refuse. 
(b)  All bills for service hereafter shall be due and payable monthly for service commencing with billings on or after March 1, 2013. For any total account balance, including electricity, water, sewer or solid waste service billed, that has not been paid by the date due, a late fee of five percent of the delinquent account balance, with a minimum late fee of $5.00, will be added to the account. 
(c)  Any customer being billed for garbage collection only and whose account becomes delinquent will be subject to the city's collection policy. 
(Ord. No. 2012-319, § 1, 12-4-12) 
Sec. 82-97. - Exceptions to the service charge. 
(a)  Any household whose sole source of income is Social Security Benefits shall be granted an exemption from the payment of any service charge required under section 82-96, provided the household seeking to claim the exemption shall present proof of income to the county health officer no later than the first billing date of any calendar year in which the exemption is desired. The county health officer shall notify the city utility collections office in writing of the intention to grant a certificate of exception and no such certificate of exception shall be granted for an individual household without prior written approval of the city finance director or his or her designee. The exemption shall apply only so long as the household's sole source of income is Social Security and shall be requested each year in which the exemption is desired. Falsification of records is a class "C" felony. 
(b)  If a household is expected to be vacant for a minimum of three months, an application for exemption of the service charge may be submitted to the city utility collections division. Upon approval of the application, the garbage cart will be removed from the household. If the household is not vacant for a minimum of three months, the household will be assessed the unbilled service charge. Any exemption will be applied only after application is approved. 
(Ord. No. 2012-319, § 1, 12-4-12) 
Secs. 82-98-82-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - LITTERING, UNAUTHORIZED ACTIVITIES 

Sec. 82-111. - Unauthorized dumping is littering. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly deposit in any manner litter on any public or private property or in any public or private waters having no permission to do so. 
(b)  For purposes of this subdivision, items found in an accumulation of garbage, trash or other discarded material including, but not limited to, bank statements, utility bills, bank card bills, and other financial documents, clearly bearing the name of a person shall constitute a rebuttable presumption that the person whose name appears thereon knowingly deposited the litter. Advertising, marketing, and campaign materials and literature shall not be sufficient to constitute a rebuttable presumption of criminal littering under this subsection. 
(c)  No action for criminal littering based on evidence that creates a rebuttable presumption under subsection (a) shall be brought against a person unless he or she has been given written notice by a designee of the city commission that items found in an accumulation of garbage, trash, or other discarded materials contain his or her name, and that, under subsection (a), there is a rebuttable presumption that he or she knowingly deposited the litter. The notice shall advise the person that criminal littering is a misdemeanor, and shall provide that, unless the person can present satisfactory information or evidence to rebut the presumption to the designee of the governing body within 15 days of the date of the notice, an action for criminal littering may be filed against him in the municipal court. If the person responds to the notice and presents information or evidence to the designee of the city commission, the designee shall review the information or evidence presented and make a determination as to whether or not an action should be brought against the person for criminal littering. The designee shall provide written notice to the person of its determination, and if the intent is to proceed with an action for criminal littering, the notice shall be sent before any action is filed. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-3-07) 
State Law reference- Ala. Code 1975 Sec. 13A-7-29. 
Sec. 82-112. - Carrying material; trucking foreign material. 
    The owner, lessee or operator of every vehicle engaged in hauling any sand, gravel, dirt, stone, rock, brick, coal, limestone, limestone dust, asphalt, garbage, trash, or any material which, as a result of such a vehicle movement, may be likely to blow, fall or be scattered on or along city streets and alleys shall maintain such a vehicle in a secure condition and shall direct and supervise the loading of said vehicle in such a manner as to prevent any portion of such materials, products or substances from falling, blowing or being scattered on city streets or alleys. Nor shall garbage or other materials offensive to the sight or smell be removed or carried on or along the streets and alleys of the city except in trucks having watertight beds or boxes with proper cover. All vehicles transporting solid waste or other aforementioned material in public places shall be covered or tarped during transportation, and shall be secured to prevent such materials, products, or substances from blowing, falling, or scattering on city streets or other public places. No person shall drive or more any vehicle or truck within the city, the wheels and tires of which carry onto or deposit in any street, alley or other public place, mud, dirt, sticky substances, "litter" or foreign matter of any kind. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-3-07) 
Sec. 82-113. - Burning refuse on streets, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any persons to burn, or cause to be burned, refuse on any street, alley, highway, or right-of-way thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2007-117, § 1, 4-3-07)
