    The extent and parameters of a development plan approval or administrative authorization for a facility shall be as follows: 
(a)  A development plan approval or administrative authorization shall not be assigned, transferred or conveyed without the express prior written notification to the city, such notice to be not fewer than 30 business days prior to the intended assignment, transfer or conveyance. 
(b)  A transfer, assignment or other conveyance of the development plan approval or administrative authorization shall require the written commitment of the new holder of the development plan approval or administrative authorization to abide by all applicable laws, rules and regulations, including but not limited to this chapter. 
(c)  Following notice and an opportunity to cure and if not cured, a development plan approval or administrative authorization granted under this chapter may be revoked, canceled, or terminated for a violation of the conditions and provisions of the development plan approval or other applicable law, rule or regulation, and if warranted the payment of a fine(s) as is permissible. 
(d)  If not cured within the time frame set forth in the notice of violation, a hearing shall be held upon due prior notice to the applicant citing the violation(s) and the date, time and place of the hearing, which shall be provided by registered mail to the last known address of the holder of the development plan approval. 
(e)  Following the original notice and an opportunity to cure as relates to a given facility, subsequent or repeated violations of a substantially similar nature shall not require an opportunity to cure prior to the imposition of fines. 
(Ord. No. 2017-1, § 2, 1-3-17) 
Sec. 96-21. - Removal and performance security. 
    Support structure removal and performance: The applicant and the owner of record of any proposed new tower or support structure shall, at its sole cost and expense, be required to execute and file with the city a bond or other form of security that is acceptable to the city as to the type of security and the form and manner of execution, in an amount of at least $75,000.00 for a tower or other support structure and with such sureties as are deemed adequate by the city to assure the faithful performance of the terms and conditions of this chapter and conditions of any development plan approval issued pursuant to this chapter. The full amount of the bond or security shall remain in full force and effect throughout the term of the development plan approval and/or until any necessary site restoration is completed to restore the site to a condition comparable to that which existed prior to the issuance of the original development plan approval. 
(Ord. No. 2017-1, § 2, 1-3-17) 
Sec. 96-22. - Reservation of authority to inspect wireless telecommunications facilities. 
(a)  In order to verify that the holder of a development plan approval for facility and any and all lessees, renters, and/or licensees of wireless telecommunications facilities, place and construct and operate such facilities in accordance with all applicable technical, safety, fire, building codes, zoning codes, laws, ordinances and regulations and conditions of any permit granted under this chapter, the city may inspect, or cause to have inspected by a third party, all facets of said permit holder's, renter's, lessee's or licensee's placement, construction, modification and maintenance of such facilities, including, but not limited to, towers, antennas and buildings or other structures constructed or located on the permitted site, including but not limited to electrical service, wiring and components. 
(b)  Refusal to allow or grant access to a city representative upon reasonable notice shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2017-1, § 2, 1-3-17) 
Sec. 96-23. - Liability insurance. 
(a)  A holder of a development plan approval for a wireless telecommunications support structure shall secure and at all times maintain public liability insurance for personal injuries, death and property damage, and umbrella insurance coverage, for the duration of the development plan approval in amounts as set forth below: 
(1)  Commercial general liability covering personal injuries, death and property damage: $1,000,000.00 per occurrence/$2,000,000.00 aggregate; and 
(2)  Automobile coverage: $1,000,000.00 per occurrence/$2,000,000.00 aggregate; and 
(3)  A $3,000,000.00 umbrella coverage; and 
(4)  Workers compensation and disability: Statutory amounts. 
(b)  For a facility located on city property, the commercial general liability insurance policy shall specifically name the city and its officers, boards, employees, committee members, attorneys, agents and consultants as additional insureds. 
(c)  The insurance policies shall contain an endorsement obligating the insurance company to furnish the city with at least 30 days prior written notice in advance of the cancellation of the insurance. 
(d)  Renewal or replacement policies or certificates shall be delivered to the city at least 15 days prior to the expiration of the insurance that such policies are to renew or replace. 
(e)  Before construction of a permitted wireless telecommunications facility is initiated, but in no case later than 15 days prior to the grant of the building permit, the holder of the development plan approval or administrative authorization shall deliver to the city a copy of each of the policies or certificates representing the insurance in the required amounts. 
(f)  A certificate of insurance that states that it is for informational purposes only and does not confer rights upon the city shall not be deemed to comply with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2017-1, § 2, 1-3-17) 
Sec. 96-24. - Indemnification. 
(a)  Any application for wireless telecommunication facilities that is proposed to be located on city property shall contain a provision with respect to indemnification of the city. Such provision shall require the applicant, to the extent permitted by applicable law, to at all times defend, indemnify, protect, save, hold harmless and exempt the city and its officers, commissions, committees, employees, attorneys, agents, and consultants from any and all penalties, damages, costs, or charges arising out of any and all claims, suits, demands, causes of action, or award of damages, whether compensatory or punitive, or expenses arising therefrom, either at law or in equity, which might arise out of, or are caused by, the placement, construction, erection, modification , location, products performance, use, operation, maintenance, repair, installation, replacement, removal, or restoration of said facility, excepting, however, any portion of such claims, suits, demands, causes of action or award of damages as may be attributable to the negligent or intentional acts or omissions of the city, or its servants or agents. With respect to the penalties, damages or charges referenced herein, reasonable attorneys' fees, consultants' fees, and expert witness fees are included in those costs that are recoverable by the city. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the requirements noted in subsection (a) of this section, an indemnification provision will not be required in those instances where the city itself applies for and secures a development plan approval for a wireless telecommunications facility. 
(Ord. No. 2017-1, § 2, 1-3-17) 
Sec. 96-25. - Fines. 
(a)  In the event of a violation of this chapter, or any development plan approval or administrative authorization or building permit issued pursuant to this chapter, the city may impose and collect, and the holder of the development plan approval or administrative authorization shall pay to the city fines or penalties as established by the city and as allowed by state law. 
(b)  Notwithstanding anything in this chapter, the holder of the development plan approval or administrative authorization for a facility may not use the payment of fines, liquidated damages or other penalties, to evade or avoid compliance with this chapter or any section of this chapter. An attempt to do so shall subject the holder of the development plan approval, to termination and revocation of the development plan approval or administrative authorization. Without limiting other remedies available to the city, the city may also seek injunctive relief to prevent the continued violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2017-1, § 2, 1-3-17) 
Sec. 96-26. - Responsible party(s). 
    The owner(s) of a facility, including any support structure used to accommodate wireless facilities and equipment, and the owner of the land upon which a facility or support structure is located, shall at all times be jointly and severally responsible for: (1) the physical and safe condition of the facility and all components on the site related to the facility; (2) assuring that all activities of owners, users, or lessees occurring on the site, and all components on the site related to the facility, are at all times in compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances, rules, regulations, orders, and permits related to the facility; and (3) assuring the proper permitting as required by this article and other city regulations by all owners of equipment, lessees and users of the facility, including but not limited to any upgrades and/or modifications of equipment. Said owner(s) shall monitor activities at the site to assure that the facility is operated in compliance with this chapter, other city regulations, and any special or conditional use permit. 
(Ord. No. 2017-1, § 2, 1-3-17) 
Sec. 96-27. - Default and/or revocation. 
    If a support structure or facility is repaired, rebuilt, placed, moved, re-located, modified or maintained in a way that is inconsistent or not in compliance with the provisions of this chapter or of the development plan approval or administrative authorization, then the city shall notify the holder of the development plan approval or administrative authorization in writing of such violation. A permit or administrative authorization holder found to be in violation may be considered in default and subject to fines as permitted under applicable state law, and if a violation is not corrected to the satisfaction of the city in a reasonable period of time the development plan approval or administrative authorization shall be subject to revocation. 
(Ord. No. 2017-1, § 2, 1-3-17) 
Sec. 96-28. - Removal or moving of wireless telecommunications structures and facilities. 
(a)  If attached to an existing structure, unless the planning director deems doing so to be in the public interest, it shall be impermissible for a wireless service provider's or carrier's facilities and equipment to be moved or relocated from one structure to another, or replaced by the construction of a new facility, without proof that not to be relocated to or replaced by a facility at another location would for technical reasons prohibit or serve to prohibit the provision of service in the service area served by the existing wireless facility. 
(b)  If the lease for the existing co-location expires and is not renewed, thereby forcing the facility to be moved, such move shall be allowed only upon i) the provision of convincing evidence satisfactory to the city of the need to move or relocate the facility; and ii) convincing evidence satisfactory to the city of the lack of impact on the neighborhood or area of intended new location. Cancellation or abandonment of a lease by a wireless service provider or carrier or other lessee, shall not be deemed a permissible reason for relocating. 
(c)  The owner of any facility shall be required to provide a minimum of 90 days written notice to the city clerk prior to abandoning any facility. 
(d)  Under the following circumstances, the city may determine that the health, safety, and welfare interests of the city warrant and require the removal of facilities. 
(1)  A facility has been abandoned (i.e. not used as a wireless telecommunications facility) for a period exceeding 90 consecutive days or a total of 180 non-consecutive days in any 365-day period, except for periods caused by force majeure or Acts of God, in which case, repair or removal shall be completed within 90 days of abandonment; 
(2)  A support structure or facility falls into such a state of disrepair that it creates a health or safety hazard or is deemed an attractive nuisance or a visual blight; 
(3)  A support structure or facility has been located, constructed, or modified without first obtaining, or in a manner not authorized by the required development plan approval or administrative authorization, and the special permit or administrative authorization may be revoked. 
(4)  If the city makes a determination as noted in subsection (2) or (3) of this section, then the city shall notify the holder of the permit or administrative authorization for the facility within 48 hours that said facility is to be brought into compliance and conformity or removed. 
a.  The holder of the development plan approval or administrative authorization, or its successors or assigns, shall dismantle and remove such facility and all associated structures and equipment from the site and restore the site to as close to its original condition as is possible, such restoration being limited only by physical or commercial impracticability. Restoration shall be completed within 90 days of receipt of written notice from the city. However, if the owner of the property upon which the facility is located wishes to retain any access roadway to the facility, the owner may do so with the approval of the city. 
b.  If a facility has not been removed, or substantial progress has not been made to remove the facility, within 90 days after the permit holder has received notice, then the city may order officials or representatives of the city to remove the facility at the sole expense of the owner or development plan approval holder. 
c.  If the city removes, or causes facilities to be removed, and the owner of the facility does not claim and remove the material from the site to a lawful location within ten days, then the city may take steps to declare the facility a nuisance. 
d.  Notwithstanding anything in this chapter to the contrary, the city may approve a temporary use permit/agreement for the facility for no more than 90 days duration, during which time a suitable plan for removal, conversion, or re-location of the affected facility shall be developed by the holder of the development plan approval, subject to the approval of the city, and an agreement to such plan shall be executed by the holder of the development plan approval or administrative authorization and the city. If such a plan is not developed, approved and executed within the 90-day time period, then the city may take possession of and dispose of the affected facility in the manner provided in this chapter and utilize the performance and removal bond. 
(Ord. No. 2017-1, § 2, 1-3-17) 
Sec. 96-29. - RF emissions. 
(a)  To assure the protection of the public health and safety, the city expressly reserves the right to require that an applicant, a user of a facility or the owner of the facility verify compliance with the FCC's regulations regarding RF emissions, either for individually-owned equipment or cumulatively for all equipment at the site, as may be deemed appropriate from time to time, and that all users of the facility cooperate with the party responsible for such verification. 
(b)  With respect to support structures other than towers, if any section or portion of the structure or the entire site or within 100 feet of the boundaries of the site, is not in compliance with the FCC's regulations regarding RF radiation, that section or portion must be barricaded with a suitable barrier to discourage approaching into the area in excess of the FCC's regulations, and be marked off with brightly colored plastic chain or striped warning tape as appropriate, as well as placing RF Radiation warning signs as needed and appropriate to warn individuals of the potential danger. 
(Ord. No. 2017-1, § 2, 1-3-17) 
Sec. 96-30. - Relief. 
(a)  Any applicant desiring relief, waiver or exemption from any aspect or requirement of this chapter shall address and identify such at the pre-application meeting. The relief or exemption must be contained in the submitted application for either a development plan approval or administrative authorization, or in the case of an existing or previously granted development plan approval or administrative authorization, a request for modification of the facility and/or equipment. Such relief may be temporary or permanent, partial or complete. 
(b)  If relief waiver or exemption for any item or issue is not requested at the pre-application meeting and is requested after the submittal of the application, the city reserves the right to require a formal amendment of the application, including the payment of all fees and charges. 
(c)  The burden of proving the need for the requested relief, waiver or exemption shall be solely on the applicant. 
(d)  The applicant shall bear all costs of the city in considering the request and the relief, waiver or exemption. 
(e)  No relief, waiver or exemption shall be approved unless the applicant demonstrates by clear and convincing evidence that, if granted, the relief, waiver or exemption will have no significant effect on the health, safety and welfare of the city, its residents and other service providers. 
(f)  Relief, waiver or exemption may not be granted by administrative authority. All requests for relief, waiver or exemption will be presented to the planning commission for approval and will require a public hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2017-1, § 2, 1-3-17) 
Sec. 96-31. - Adherence to state and/or federal rules and regulations. 
(a)  To the extent that the holder of a development plan approval or administrative authorization for a wireless telecommunications facility has not received relief, or is otherwise exempt, from appropriate state and/or federal agency rules or regulations, then the holder of such a development plan approval shall adhere to, and comply with, all applicable rules, regulations, standards, and provisions of any state or federal agency, including, but not limited to, the FAA and the FCC. Specifically included in this requirement are any rules and regulations regarding height, lighting, security, electrical and RF emission standards. 
(b)  To the extent that applicable rules, regulations, standards, and provisions of any state or federal agency, including but not limited to, the FAA and the FCC, and specifically including any rules and regulations regarding height, lighting, and security are changed and/or are modified during the duration of a development plan approval or administrative authorization for wireless telecommunications facilities, then the holder of such a development plan approval or administrative authorization shall conform the permitted facility to the applicable changed and/or modified rule, regulation, standard, or provision within a maximum of 24 months of the effective date of the applicable changed and/or modified rule, regulation, standard, or provision, or sooner as may be required by the issuing entity. 
(Ord. No. 2017-1, § 2, 1-3-17) 
Sec. 96-32. - Conflict with other laws. 
    Where this chapter differs or conflicts with other laws, rules and regulations, unless the right to do so is preempted or prohibited by the city, state or federal government, this chapter shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 2017-1, § 2, 1-3-17) 
Sec. 96-33. - Effective date. 
    This chapter shall be effective immediately upon passage, pursuant to applicable legal and procedural requirements. 
(Ord. No. 2017-1, § 2, 1-3-17) 
Sec. 96-34. - Authority. 
    This chapter is enacted pursuant to applicable authority granted by the state and federal government. 
(Ord. No. 2017-1, § 2, 1-3-17) 
Chapter 98 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Moving buildings, § 14-1; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86. 
State Law reference- Operation of vehicles generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 98-1. - Misdemeanors under state law adopted by reference. 
    All provisions of law relating to the speed and operation of motor vehicles in the city are hereby adopted by the city, including all rules of the state and all rules and regulations of the state highway department pertaining to the control of traffic and motor vehicles on highways that are misdemeanors under the state laws. A violation of such laws, rules and regulations in the city or in the police jurisdiction of the city shall be violations of this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 19-31.1) 
State Law reference- Rules of the road generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-1 et seq. 
Sec. 98-2. - Fines for violation. 
    Any person convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter shall be fined in accordance with the Alabama Uniform Traffic Citation Law schedule of fines, per section 98-52 or section 1-4, as applicable, unless otherwise noted. 
(Code 1977, § 19-31.2) 
Sec. 98-3. - Speed limits. 
(a)  No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a greater speed than 30 miles per hour on any street or alley, unless otherwise indicated by proper signs or markings. 
(b)  Speed limits on city streets, other than state or federal roads, shall be determined and posted by the city traffic engineer. 
(Code 1977, § 19-31) 
Sec. 98-3.1. - Establishment of state speed zone. 
(a)  No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a speed greater than 55 miles per hour in the following listed zones of the city: 
(1)  On Alabama Highway No. 53 (US 231), from the north Dothan city limits, mile post No. 27.81, thence southerly for a distance of 1.25 miles to John D. Odom Road, mile post No. 26.56. 
(2)  On Alabama Highway No. 12 (US 84), from the west Dothan city limits, mile post No. 203.06, thence easterly for a distance of 1.48 miles to Brannon Stand Road, mile post No. 204.54. 
(b)  No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a speed greater than 50 miles per hour in the following listed zones of the city: 
(1)  On Alabama Highway No. 53 (US 231), from John D. Odom Road, mile post No. 26.56, thence southerly for a distance of 0.52 miles to Napier Field Road, mile post No. 26.04. 
(2)  On Alabama Highway No. 12 (US 84), from Brannon Stand Road, mile post No. 204.54, thence easterly for a distance of 0.96 miles to Grove Park Road, mile post No. 205.50. 
(c)  No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a speed greater than 45 miles per hour in the following listed zones of the city: 
(1)  On Alabama Highway No. 53 (US 231), from Napier Field Road, mile post No. 26.04, thence southerly for a distance of 1.2 miles to Westgate Parkway, mile post No. 24.84. 
(2)  On Alabama Highway No. 12 (US 84), from Grove Park Road, mile post No. 205.50, thence easterly for a distance of 1.63 miles to Flowers Chapel Road, mile post No. 207.13. 
(d)  No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a speed greater than 40 miles per hour in the following listed zones of the city: 
(1)  On Alabama Highway No. 53 (US 231), from Westgate Parkway, mile post No. 24.84, thence southerly for a distance of 0.73 miles to Ross Clark Circle (SR 210), mile post No. 24.11. 
(2)  On Alabama Highway No. 12 (US 84), from Flowers Chapel Road, mile post No. 207.13, thence easterly for a distance of 0.46 miles to Ross Clark Circle (SR 210), mile post No. 207.59. 
(Ord. No. 2007-384, § 1, 11-6-07) 
Sec. 98-4. - U-turns. 
    The driver of a vehicle shall not make a U-turn or turn such a vehicle so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon any public street, except as provided in the state traffic laws. 
(Code 1977, § 19-26) 
Sec. 98-5. - One-way streets. 
    When appropriate signs are erected giving notice thereof, vehicular traffic shall move only in the indicated direction of travel upon public streets or parts of such streets within the city. 
(Code 1977, § 19-28) 
Sec. 98-6. - Evading traffic regulations by crossing premises of another. 
    Unless specifically directed by someone with authority to do so for the purpose of alleviating the congestion of traffic, it shall be unlawful to drive a vehicle across the premises of another, even though such premises may be a service station or similar business, for the purpose of or which results in evading traffic signs, signals, markings or other traffic regulations and control devices. 
(Code 1977, § 19-27) 
Sec. 98-7. - Manner of driving vehicles in certain parking lots. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any automobile, truck, motor scooter or other self-propelled vehicle upon any parking lot, for which no charge is made for parking thereon, in excess of 20 miles per hour or in willful or wanton disregard for the safety of persons or property. 
(Code 1977, § 19-29) 
Sec. 98-8. - Interfering with traffic for the purpose of soliciting or distributing material. 
(a)  No person shall solicit contributions or pass out material on behalf of any person or organization on any public street by setting up a roadblock or otherwise interfering with traffic. 
(b)  Any person guilty of soliciting contributions or passing out any material in violation of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-4. Each offense and each day's continuance of the offense shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Code 1977, § 19-30) 
Sec. 98-9. - Funeral processions; identification. 
    A funeral composed of a procession of vehicles shall be identified in a manner designated by the police department. 
(Code 1977, § 19-19) 
Sec. 98-10. - Sight distance triangles; visual obstructions. 
(a)  At any intersection of two public roads, a 55-foot sight distance triangle must provide for an unobstructed view across the triangle formed by joining points measured 55 feet distant along the property line from the intersection of the two streets. 
(b)  Within the area of the triangle there must be no sight obscuring wall, fence, sign, foliage or berming higher than 24 inches above the curb grade or, in the case of trees, foliage lower than eight feet. 
(c)  Vertical measurement must be made from the flowlines of the two streets forming the triangle or if no gutter exists from the edge of the nearest traveled way. 
(d)  Objects that may be located in the triangular area are items such as hydrants, utility poles, utility junction boxes and traffic control devices. These must be located to minimize visual obstruction. For rounded property corners, the triangular area must be between the property lines extended and diagonal line joining the points on the property lines, 55 feet from the point of their intersection. 
(e)  Subsections (a)-(d) also apply to intersections of public roads and railroad rights-of-way at railroad crossings not controlled by gates or flashing lights. 
(Code 1977, § 19-20) 
Sec. 98-11. - Failure to remove visual obstructions. 
(a)  Should the owner or person in charge of any premises fail or refuse to remove any obstruction prohibited by section 98-10 within ten days after written notice by the city engineer or his duly authorized representative, such owner or person shall be guilty of an offense against the city. A notice shall be sent by certified mail or by personal service. 
(b)  If such owner or person in possession of such premises shall fail or refuse to remove any such obstruction within ten days after such written notice, such obstruction shall be removed by the city under the supervision of the city engineering department. The cost of such removal shall constitute a charge and lien on the property and be due by such owner or person in possession, or both. 
(Code 1977, § 19-21) 
Secs. 98-12-98-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 98-41. - Enforcement of chapter generally. 
(a)  In addition to any specific duties of this chapter, it shall be the duty of the police department to investigate traffic accidents and to arrest and to assist in the prosecution of those persons charged with violations of this chapter. 
(b)  In addition to any specific duties of this chapter, the engineering department shall be generally responsible for all traffic control devices, markings, signs and other physical methods of traffic control as related to traffic engineering, except county, state and federal routes other than by agreement. 
(Code 1977, § 19-2) 
Sec. 98-42. - Official traffic control devices-Compliance; authority to install. 
    All traffic along the streets wherein official traffic control signs, signals, devices or markings are installed shall comply therewith. The failure of any driver or pedestrian to do so shall constitute an offense against the city. Except as provided in section 98-41(b), the city traffic engineer is authorized to install and maintain and to remove such signs, signals, devices and markings as may be deemed appropriate to regulate traffic on the streets. All such acts are hereby approved and confirmed by the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1977, § 19-3) 
Sec. 98-43. - Same-Duty as to installation and timing; analysis of traffic accidents, conditions and operation; remedial measures. 
    Except as provided in section 98-41(b), it shall be the general duty of the traffic engineer to determine the installation and proper timing and maintenance of traffic control devices, signs, signals and markings; to conduct the analysis of traffic accidents and to devise remedial measures; to conduct the investigation of traffic conditions; and to plan the operation of traffic on the streets in the city. 
(Code 1977, § 19-4) 
Sec. 98-44. - Restrictions upon use of streets by certain vehicles and pedestrians. 
(a)  The city traffic engineer is hereby authorized to determine and designate those heavily traveled streets upon which shall be prohibited the use of the roadway by motor-driven cycles, bicycles, horse-drawn vehicles or other nonmotorized traffic and shall erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof. 
(b)  When signs are so erected, giving notice thereof, no person shall disobey the restrictions stated on the signs. 
(c)  When appropriate official signs are so erected, giving notice thereof, no person shall: 
(1)  As a pedestrian, occupy any space within the limits of the roadway of a controlled access highway except in the performance of public works or official duties, as a result of an emergency caused by an accident or breakdown of a motor vehicle, or to obtain assistance. 
(2)  Occupy any space within the limits of the roadway of a controlled access highway with an animal-drawn vehicle, a ridden or led animal, herded animals, a pushcart, a bicycle with a motor attached, parades, a motor-driven cycle with a motor which produces less than five brake horsepower, funeral processions, an agricultural tractor or farm machinery, except in the performance of public works or official duties. 
(Code 1977, § 19-22) 
Sec. 98-45. - Records of traffic infractions. 
    The municipal court shall keep a record of all violations of the traffic ordinances of this city or vehicle laws of the state that occur within the corporate limits of this city or the police jurisdiction of the city, together with a record of the final disposition of all such alleged offenses. Such record shall be maintained in accordance with state law or rule and as required by the municipal court. 
(Code 1977, § 19-5) 
Sec. 98-46. - Accident files to be maintained. 
    The police department shall maintain a suitable record of all traffic accidents reported for each driver. 
(Code 1977, § 19-6) 
Sec. 98-47. - Records of accidents. 
    The police department shall maintain a suitable system of filing traffic accident reports. Such reports shall be available for the use and information of the public. 
(Code 1977, § 19-7) 
Sec. 98-48. - Studies of concentrated traffic accident locations. 
    Whenever the accidents at any particular location become numerous, the traffic engineer shall conduct studies of such accidents and determine remedial measures. 
(Code 1977, § 19-8) 
Sec. 98-49. - Traffic report. 
    The police department shall prepare a traffic report, with regard to traffic accident data, annually or at the request of the commission. 
(Code 1977, § 19-9) 
Sec. 98-50. - Emergency regulations. 
    The chief of police and the city engineer are empowered and directed to make effective the provisions of this chapter and to make and enforce temporary regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions as allowed by state law. Such temporary regulations shall remain in effect until the emergency no longer exists. The city manager will be informed immediately of any action under this section. 
(Code 1977, § 19-10) 
Sec. 98-51. - Citation on illegally parked vehicle; attaching; contents. 
    Whenever any motor vehicle without a driver is found parked or stopped in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by this chapter, the officer finding such vehicle shall take its registration number and may identify its user, as well as any other facts, and shall conspicuously affix a citation to such vehicle on a form provided by the city, notifying the driver to answer to the charge against him within 14 days at a place specified in the citation. Proof that the vehicle was registered to a person on the date of the citation shall be prima facie evidence that such registered owner is responsible for such act. 
(Code 1977, § 19-12) 
Sec. 98-52. - Fines and forfeitures-Schedule; disposition. 
(a)  Schedule of fines for traffic infractions. If a defendant in a municipal court case elects to plead guilty before a magistrate to one of the traffic offenses listed in the following schedule, the fine established in the schedule shall apply:

(d)  All fines or forfeitures collected upon conviction or upon the forfeiture of bail of any person shall be deposited in accordance with city policy and with the state law. 
(Code 1977, § 19-16; Ord. No. 2003-304, § 1, 10-21-03) 
Sec. 98-53. - Same-Noncompliance constitutes official misconduct. 
    Failure, refusal or neglect on the part of any judicial or other officer or employee receiving or having custody of any such fine or forfeiture to comply with the provisions of section 90-52(d), shall constitute misconduct in office and shall be grounds for removal therefrom. 
(Code 1977, § 19-17) 
Sec. 98-54. - Audit of record and reports. 
    The records of state uniform traffic citations, other forms of traffic charges and warrants issued therefor required in this chapter shall be audited at least annually by a person designated by the commission to make annual financial audits. That person shall submit a report of such audit, together with a summary thereof to the commission. Such reports shall be public records. 
(Code 1977, § 19-18) 
Secs. 98-55-98-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARKING, STANDING AND STOPPING 

Sec. 98-86. - Parallel parking required unless otherwise indicated. 
(a)  No person shall stand or park a vehicle upon a public street in a business district or other heavily traveled street, whether marked to designate parking or not, other than parallel, with the edge of the roadway headed in the direction of lawful traffic movement and with the right-hand wheels of the vehicle within 18 inches of the curb or edge of the roadway, except as otherwise provided in this article. Vehicles may be parked on the shoulder of the roadway, if they are at least two feet from the edge of the roadway, unless otherwise prohibited. 
(b)  Where signs are placed or erected or spaces are clearly marked off in a block, giving notice of parallel or angle parking, as the case may be, no person shall park a vehicle to the contrary or allow such vehicle to obstruct others from parking as directed. 
(Code 1977, § 19-32) 
Sec. 98-87. - Use of street and right-of-way. 
(a)  Except for public service signs, motorist information signs and public conveniences specifically approved by the board of commissioners or the state highway department, it shall be unlawful for any person to park or place any vehicle, equipment or object, including automobiles, trailers, mobile homes, signs and other vehicles, equipment or objects on any street or public right-of-way for the purpose of: 
(1)  Displaying such vehicles, equipment or objects for sale, lease or hire; storing such vehicles, equipment or objects; or using such vehicles, equipment or objects for advertising purposes, except advertising which is incidental to the normal operation of such vehicle, equipment or object. 
(2)  Working on, greasing or repairing such vehicles, equipment or objects, except repairs necessitated by an emergency. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to stand, sit or walk on any street or public right-of-way for the purpose of advertising any product or service. 
(c)  Violation of this section shall be punishable as provided for in section 1-4. 
(Code 1977, § 19-33) 
Sec. 98-88. - Parking on city premises. 
(a)  No person shall park a vehicle on the premises of the city where such space has been reserved, and notice of such reservation is given, by placing notice thereof at such space. 
(b)  Persons shall park vehicles only in an area designated for parking and for a time not exceeding the posted time limit as applicable. 
(Code 1977, § 19-34) 
Sec. 98-89. - Violations of article. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or operated by such person to be parked overtime or beyond the period of the maximum legal parking time established; 
(2)  Permit any vehicle to remain or be placed in any parking space when the vehicle occupying such parking space has already been parked beyond the period of the maximum legal parking time established; or 
(3)  Park any vehicle across any line or markings of a parking space or in such position that the vehicle shall not be entirely within the area designated by such lines or markings. 
(Code 1977, § 19-35) 
Sec. 98-90. - Parking in violation of yellow-painted curb or of signs. 
    No persons shall park a motor vehicle in any prohibited area when such area is properly marked by curbs painted yellow or notice is given by installed signs to persons engaged in maintenance or construction of streets, drainage or utilities, properly authorized or permitted by the city engineer, nor to the driver of any ambulance while picking up or discharging any ill, injured or deceased person. 
(Code 1977, § 19-36) 
Sec. 98-91. - Vehicles heavier than one ton; prohibited and permitted parking. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to stop, stand or park a trailer, tractor, truck or other motor-operated vehicle heavier than a one-ton pickup truck at any time on the public streets in residential sections of the city, except while the operator of such vehicle is actually engaged in loading or unloading lawful contents to or from such vehicle, and except during an emergency or in compliance with the law or the directions of a police officer or other traffic control device or markings. 
(Code 1977, § 19-37) 
Sec. 98-92. - Parking spaces designated for physically handicapped persons. 
(a)  The city traffic engineer is hereby authorized to designate marked parking spaces within any private parking lot in the city limits, serving the general public and having 25 spaces or more, within any city block or upon any city property for the exclusive parking of motor vehicles driven by or in use by physically handicapped persons. 
(b)  Parking spaces for the handicapped will be designated by the international parking sign for the handicapped. 
(c)  Permits for the parking of vehicles operated by physically handicapped persons in parking spaces designated for such purpose are those permits issued by the judge of probate or license commissioner, as set out and regulated by Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-6-231. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for: 
(1)  Any person to park any vehicle not displaying the permit in an area designated for handicapped parking; or 
(2)  For the registered owner of a vehicle to allow his vehicle to be so parked. 
(e)  Proof that the vehicle was registered to such person on the day of the violation shall be prima facie evidence that such registered owner is responsible for such act. 
(Code 1977, § 19-38) 
Secs. 98-93-98-125. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TRUCKS AND COMMERCIAL VEHICLES 

Sec. 98-126. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial vehicle means those vehicles which have three or more axles and/or are 33 feet or more in length, including those vehicles with enclosed or open bodies attached to the chassis and trailers when attached to power-driven units, but shall not include city vehicles, school buses, recreational vehicles, vehicles housing mobile health clinic units and equipment providing physical screening processes in or on such units. 
(Code 1977, § 19-25(c)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 98-127. - Authority of traffic engineer to designate load restrictions on certain streets. 
(a)  The city traffic engineer is hereby authorized, on the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation, to impose gross weight limits and to erect and maintain official traffic-control devices on any streets or parts of streets to prohibit the operation of vehicles exceeding such posted weights at any time on any of the streets or parts of streets designated by the city traffic engineer; provided, however, that such devices shall not prohibit necessary local operation on such streets for the purpose of making a pickup or delivery. 
(b)  The city traffic engineer shall maintain a current copy of a schedule, designating such streets and parts of streets so regulated, on file in the office of the city clerk and in the office of the city traffic engineer. 
(c)  When signs are erected giving notice, no person shall operate any vehicle with a gross weight in excess of the amounts designated by the city traffic engineer at any time upon any of the streets or parts of streets specified by the city traffic engineer, unless such person shall have first obtained a special written permit from the city traffic engineer. 
(Code 1977, § 19-23) 
State Law reference- Size and weight of vehicles, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-9-20 et seq. 
Sec. 98-128. - Operation of oversize vehicles and loads; scope of permit requirements. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or move on any public street within the city, or the police jurisdiction of the city, any motor vehicle or load thereon which exceeds the maximum width, height and length prescribed by state law or city ordinance, unless such person shall have obtained a special written permit approved by the police department and traffic engineer, except for the moving of buildings, which requirements are in sections 14-1, 14-27 and subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Application for such special permit must be made not less than 24 hours before such motor vehicle or load is to be driven or moved upon such streets. The applicant shall pay the cost of any city services required for the move, such as police escort, utility relocation, etc. For police escort, the application for the permit shall be accompanied by minimum fee of $100.00 which shall cover the costs of up to two hours for two officers to provide police escort. If the moving time exceeds two hours, the applicant shall be billed for the additional time at $40.00 per hour for each officer assigned to the escort. Building moving requires additional costs as prescribed in sections 14-1 and 14-27. The minimum escort service fee for building moving shall be paid in conjunction with the building permit and in addition to the fees required in chapter 14. 
(c)  Such permits shall be issued and may be renewed upon such terms and conditions in the interest of public safety and the preservation of the public streets as the city traffic engineer may, in his discretion, require. He may designate the route over which such vehicle may be moved and the hours of movement of the vehicle in coordination with the police department. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall apply to the movement of any such motor vehicle on any state highway where the driver of such motor vehicle has first obtained a special permit from the director of the state highway department for such movement over such state highways within the city limits as provided by law. 
(Code 1977, § 19-24) 
State Law reference- Size and weight of vehicles, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-9-20 et seq. 
Sec. 98-129. - Authority of traffic engineer to restrict operation of commercial vehicles to designated truck routes. 
(a)  The city traffic engineer is hereby authorized, on the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation, to designate truck routes, in addition to those designated in this section, upon which commercial vehicles are restricted and to erect and maintain official traffic control devices on any streets or parts of streets restricting the operation of commercial vehicles to the streets or parts of streets designated by the city traffic engineer; provided, however, that such devices shall not prohibit necessary local operation on such streets for the purpose of making a pickup or delivery. 
(b)  The city traffic engineer shall maintain a current copy of a schedule, designating such streets and parts of streets so regulated, on file in the office of the city clerk and in the office of the city traffic engineer. 
(c)  No person shall operate any commercial vehicle on any street or part of a street, except a street designated as a truck route by the city traffic engineer; provided, however, that a driver may operate such a vehicle on a street not designated as a truck route for the purpose of making a delivery, loading or servicing by leaving a street designated as a truck route at an intersection which is nearest the place of delivery, loading or servicing, proceeding by the most direct route and then returning to the nearest street designated as a truck route by the most direct route; and provided further that a driver of such a vehicle may enter the city from a street or road outside of the city and operate such a vehicle on a street not designated as a truck route for the purpose of making a delivery, loading or servicing at a location nearer by the most direct route to the point of entry than from any street designated as a truck route; provided that such driver proceeds to such location by the most direct route from the point of entry and, after making such delivery, loading or servicing, returns by the most direct route to the point of entry. 
(d)  The following city streets are hereby designated as truck routes: 
Murray Road, from the intersection of Zenith Road eastwardly to U.S. Hwy. 431 North; Zenith Road, Rogers Road, Loftin Road, Speigner Road, Twitchell Road; Wilson Street, from the intersection of U.S. Hwy. 431 North to Twitchell Road; Bic Road, Jeffcoat Industrial Drive, Miskell Drive, Sinnett Avenue, Merrill Road; Wilson Street, from the intersection of North Range to Kinsey Road; Old Kinsey Road, from the intersection of Wilson Street to Sinnett Avenue; Wiregrass Way, Circle Drive, Wedgewood Drive, Phil Forrester Road, Kelley Drive; North Beverlye Road, from the intersection of Kelley Drive northerly to AL Highway 52; Woodburn Drive, from the intersection of Edgefield Drive to the intersection of U.S. Hwy. 84 West; West Carroll Street, between Ross Clark Circle and U.S. Hwy. 231 South; South Park, between West Carroll and Ross Clark Circle; Southgate Road, Inez Road; Westgate Parkway, from 2,000 feet west of Seaboard Coastline Railroad to the intersection with U.S. Highway 431; Headland Avenue, from the intersection of Westgate Parkway to Ross Clark Circle; Harrison Road from the intersection of Technology Drive to Mance Newton Road; Mance Newton Road, from the intersection of Harrison Road to the Dothan City Limits; Technology Drive, from the intersection of Headland Avenue to Harrison Road; Range Street, from the intersection of Wilson Street to the Ross Clark Circle; and Hodgesville Road from the Ross Clark Circle to the Flying J. truck access. 
(e)  Ross Clark Circle is designated as the through commercial vehicle route, thereby no through commercial vehicle shall be permitted on any city route inside the Ross Clark Circle. Signs shall be erected and maintained by the state department of transportation directing through commercial vehicles to the Ross Clark Circle. Commercial vehicles needing to access areas for pickup, delivery, or providing services inside the Ross Clark Circle shall enter on the intersecting street that provides the nearest access point to the destination. The city can place no restrictions on commercial vehicle traffic on federal and state highways, except where approved by the state department of transportation. 
(Code 1977, § 19-25; Ord. No. 2005-224, § 1, 8-9-05) 
Secs. 98-130-98-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ABANDONED VEHICLES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Abandoned motor vehicles generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-13-1 et seq. 

Sec. 98-161. - Abandoning vehicles or property on streets. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any vehicle or other property to be abandoned, unclaimed or unattended upon any street or city premises within the city or within its police jurisdiction for a period of over seven calendar days. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any partially dismantled or nonoperating or wrecked or junked or discarded vehicle or any vehicle without a current tag or any combination thereof to be kept on private real property for more than seven consecutive calendar days. This shall not prevent a person from working on one private vehicle for the purpose of restoration, provided the vehicle is kept within a completely screened enclosure, nor shall this subsection apply to vehicles being repaired on the premises of licensed automobile repair shops or body repair shops, provided that such vehicles are kept within a completely screened enclosure, or to automobiles on the premises of licensed junkyards, auto wrecking yards or auto salvage yards, provided that such vehicles are kept within a completely screened enclosure which will limit or otherwise obstruct the public's view of such vehicles. Any vehicle remaining on the premises of an automobile repair shop or a body repair shop for more than 90 days shall be deemed to be in violation of this section. 
(Code 1977, § 19-50) 
Sec. 98-162. - Impounding authorized; procedures. 
(a)  Conditions warranting impoundment. Members of the police department are hereby authorized to remove a vehicle or other property from a public street or city premises to the nearest garage or other place of safety, or to a garage or place designated or maintained by the police department, under the following circumstances: 
(1)  Violation of section 98-161; 
(2)  When a vehicle stopped or parked upon a public street constitutes an obstruction to traffic, and the person in charge of the vehicle refuses to move it or, by reasons of physical injury, is incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its custody or removal; or 
(3)  When a vehicle constitutes a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic and is left unattended upon a public street. 
(b)  Notice to owner upon removal. Whenever an officer removes a vehicle from a street or city premises, and the officer knows or is able to ascertain from the registration records in the vehicle the name and address of the owner thereof, such officer shall immediately give, or cause to be given, notice in writing to such owner of the fact of such removal and the reasons therefor and of the place to which such vehicle has been removed. Such officer shall, within five days, notify the state as required by Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-13-2(c). If any such vehicle is stored in a public garage, a copy of such notice shall be given to the proprietor of such garage. 
(c)  Notification by mail, delivery or publication; citation for violation. Whenever it is determined that a violation of subsection 98-161(b) exists, the owner, occupant or user of the private real property shall be notified in writing of the violation by certified mail or delivery by a uniformed police officer or, if the owner, occupant or user cannot be determined or located, by publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the county. If the violation is not corrected within seven calendar days after the delivery or publishing of such notice, members of the police department are hereby authorized to issue a citation for any violation of subsection 98-161(b) which shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00. The owner, occupant or user of private real property shall be responsible for such property. Each day's violation is a separate offense. 
(d)  Removal authority. Whenever an officer removes or causes a vehicle or property to be removed from a public street, such officer or those ordered by him to remove such vehicle or property, whether by hand, wrecker or otherwise, shall be deemed and considered as performing a duty of the police department and acting in a governmental capacity. 
(Code 1977, § 19-51) 
State Law reference- Related provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-47-116 and 32-13-1 et seq. 
Sec. 98-163. - Records; storage; immediate sale of perishables. 
(a)  A permanent record shall be kept by the chief of police, giving the date of the taking of each piece of such property, the place where it was found and taken and the description of the property. The property so taken shall be stored in a suitable place to protect it from deterioration; provided, however, that if the property is perishable, the property may be sold at once, without notice; in which case, the proceeds shall be held for a period of six months for the account of the owner and, if not called for within that time, shall be converted into the general fund. 
(b)  This section is not applicable to some items governed by state law, such as firearms and liquor. 
(Code 1977, § 19-52) 
Sec. 98-164. - Redemption costs; release. 
    In addition to fines and costs imposed by the municipal judge for violation of traffic regulations, those found guilty of such violation shall be required to pay the cost of removing illegally parked vehicles or property and the storage costs. No vehicle or property shall be released from storage, except upon the written order of the chief of police or his duly authorized representative. 
(Code 1977, § 19-53) 
Sec. 98-165. - When redemption authorized; rejection of bids; disposition of proceeds. 
(a)  The owner of the property taken up and stored may redeem the same at any time prior to its sale by paying the reasonable expense of taking the property in charge, its storage and maintenance and the pro rata cost of publication. 
(b)  Each article shall be sold separately and a notation recorded of the sale, which shall be kept by the chief of police, of the amount received for each article. 
(c)  The person making the sale shall have the right to reject any or all bids, if the amount bid is unreasonably low, and shall have the right to continue the sales from time to time, if no bidders are present or the amount bid is unreasonably low. 
(d)  All expenses incurred in taking up, storing, maintaining and selling the property shall be paid from the general fund of the city upon the approval of the chief of police and the commission. The gross amount of sales shall be deposited in accordance with city policy immediately after each sale. 
(Code 1977, § 19-54) 
Sec. 98-166. - Sale at public auction. 
    At least every six months, the chief of police shall sell, at public auction to the highest bidder for cash in front of the county courthouse, the property which shall have been taken up and stored for a period of three months or more. Such sales shall be made after notice of the time and place thereof is made by publication once a week for two successive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. The first publication shall be at least 20 days before the sale. 
(Code 1977, § 19-55) 
State Law reference- Taking up, storing, etc., of personal property, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-116. 
Secs. 98-167-98-195. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - BICYCLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Bicycles generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-260 et seq. 

Sec. 98-196. - Application of article. 
(a)  The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this article. 
(b)  This article shall apply whenever a bicycle is operated upon any public street or upon any public path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles, subject to those exceptions stated in this article. 
(Code 1977, § 19-59) 
Sec. 98-197. - Riding and carrying passengers. 
(a)  A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other than upon or astride a permanent and regular seat attached thereto. 
(b)  No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time than the number for which it is designed and equipped. 
(Code 1977, § 19-60) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-261. 
Sec. 98-198. - Clinging to motorized vehicles while on bicycles, coasters, rollerskates, skateboards, sleds or other toy vehicles. 
    No person riding upon any bicycle, coaster, roller skates, skateboard, sled or toy vehicle shall attach the same or himself to any motorized vehicle upon a public street. 
(Code 1977, § 19-61) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-262. 
Sec. 98-199. - Riding on public streets and bicycle paths. 
(a)  Every person operating a bicycle upon a public street shall follow all traffic signs and signals and obey the rules of the road and shall ride as near to the right side of the roadway as practicable, exercising due care when passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction. 
(b)  Persons riding bicycles upon a public street shall not ride more than two abreast, except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles. 
(c)  Whenever a usable path for bicycles has been provided adjacent to a roadway, bicycle riders shall use such path and shall not use the roadway. 
(Code 1977, § 19-62) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-263. 
Sec. 98-200. - Carrying articles. 
    No person operating a bicycle on a public street shall carry any package, bundle or article which prevents the rider from keeping at least one hand upon the handlebars. 
(Code 1977, § 19-63) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-264. 
Sec. 98-201. - Lamps and other equipment. 
(a)  Every bicycle, when in use at nighttime, shall be equipped with a lamp on the front which shall emit a white light visible from a distance of at least 500 feet to the front and with a red reflector on the rear of a type which shall be visible from all distances from 50 feet to 300 feet to the rear when directly in front of lawful upper beams of headlamps on a motor vehicle. 
(b)  Every bicycle shall be equipped with an adequate brake. 
(Code 1977, § 19-64) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-265. 
Sec. 98-202. - Riding on sidewalks. 
    Whenever any person is riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk, such person shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give an audible signal before overtaking and passing such pedestrian. 
(Code 1977, § 19-65) 
Sec. 98-203. - Speed. 
    No person shall operate a bicycle on public streets at a speed greater than that allowed for motorized vehicles. 
(Code 1977, § 19-66) 
Sec. 98-204. - Parking. 
    Bicycles parked upon a street shall only be parked against the curb or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle or against a building or at the curb in such a manner as to afford the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic. 
(Code 1977, § 19-67) 
Secs. 98-205-98-235. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PARADES AND PROCESSIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 98-236. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Chief of police means the chief of police of the city. 
    Downtown area means that section of the city lying aside the area of the Ross Clark Circle. 
    Footrace means an athletic event involving two or more persons for the purpose of competition, recreation or for the purpose of promotional publicity. 
    Parade means any parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant, footrace or procession of any kind, or any similar display, in or upon any street, park or other public place in the city. 
    Parade permit means a permit as required by this article. 
    Person means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
    Public assembly means any gathering of persons on public streets or other public places for the purposes of conducting social, recreational or residential functions. 
    Public assembly permit means a permit as required by this article. 
    Traffic means both vehicles and pedestrians. 
(Code 1977, § 19-70) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 98-237. - Public conduct during parades or public assemblies. 
(a)  Interference. No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct or impede, or interfere with any parade or public assembly or with any person, vehicle or animal participating or used in a parade or public assembly. 
(b)  Driving through parades. No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles or persons comprising a parade when such vehicles or persons are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a parade, unless specifically authorized to do so by law enforcement officers. 
(c)  Parking on parade route. The chief of police shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a highway or part thereof constituting a part of the route of a parade. The chief of police shall post signs to such effect, and it shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. No person shall be liable for parking on a street unposted in violation of this article. 
(Code 1977, § 19-79) 
Sec. 98-238. - Climbing, standing, sitting on buildings, poles, trees in business district to view parades, exhibitions or displays. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to climb, stand or sit upon the side or top of any building, pole or structure or in any tree, within any business district of the city in order to view any parade, exhibition or display, if such climbing, standing or sitting may endanger the safety of persons or property below, or if prohibited on such occasion by any officer of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 9-9) 
Sec. 98-239. - Obstructing streets by assembling. 
    Any person who shall assemble a crowd or hold a public meeting in any street without a permit from the police department, as provided in section 98-266, shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-4. 
(Code 1977, § 19-81) 
Secs. 98-240-98-265. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 98-266. - Required; exceptions. 
(a)  No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or start any parade or public assembly, unless a parade or public assembly permit shall have been obtained from the chief of police or other appropriate official or body. 
(b)  This article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Funeral processions; or 
(2)  A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
(Code 1977, § 19-71) 
Sec. 98-267. - Application. 
    A person seeking issuance of a parade or public assembly permit shall file an application with the chief of police on forms provided by such officers as follows: 
(1)  Filing period. An application for a parade or public assembly permit shall be filed with the chief of police not less than ten days nor more than 20 days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade. 
(2)  Contents. The application for a parade or public assembly permit shall set forth the following information: 
a.  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade or public assembly. 
b.  If the parade or public assembly is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of or by any organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization and of the authorized and responsible heads of such organization. 
c.  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade or public assembly chairman who will be responsible for its conduct. 
d.  The date when the parade or public assembly is to be conducted. 
e.  The hours when such parade or public assembly will start and terminate. 
f.  A statement as to whether the parade or public assembly will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed. 
g.  The location by street address of any assembly areas for such parade or public assembly. 
h.  The time at which units of the parade or public assembly will begin to assemble at any such assembly area. 
i.  The interval of space to be maintained between units of such parade. 
j.  If the parade or public assembly is designed to be held by and on behalf of or for any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall file with the chief of police a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade or public assembly authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf. 
k.  The approximate number of units and participants in the parade. 
(3)  Late applications. The chief of police, where good cause is shown therefor, shall have the authority to consider any application under this article which is filed less than one day before the date such parade or public assembly is proposed to be conducted. 
(Code 1977, § 19-72) 
Sec. 98-268. - Standards for issuance. 
(a)  The chief of police shall issue a permit, as provided for under this article, when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of the parade or public assembly will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route or location. 
(2)  The conduct of the parade or public assembly will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city. 
(3)  The conduct of such parade or public assembly will not require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of the city other than that to be occupied by the proposed line of march and areas contiguous thereto. 
(4)  The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such assembly areas. 
(5)  The conduct of such parade or public assembly will not interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment en route to a fire. 
(6)  The conduct of the parade or public assembly is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or to create a disturbance. 
(7)  The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route. 
(8)  The parade or public assembly is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any product, goods or event and is not designed to be held purely for private profit. 
(9)  If he deems necessary, he may require the applicant to designate a certain number of parade marshals who shall be responsible for conducting the parade or assembly in an orderly manner. 
(b)  Restrictions on the issuance of permits are as follows: 
(1)  The only parades authorized to utilize Main Street are the annual National Peanut Festival Parade, the Azalea-Dogwood Parade, the Christmas Parade and the Veteran's Day Parade. Others may utilize Main Street as a parade route only upon prior approval of the board of commissioners and upon acquiring a permit from the chief of police. 
(2)  Assembly permits for neighborhood gatherings must be cleared by the police and fire department prior to approval by the chief of police. Petitioners will be required to engage security and traffic control personnel if deemed necessary by either the police chief or the fire chief. 
(Code 1977, § 19-72.1) 
Sec. 98-269. - Contents. 
    Each parade or public assembly permit shall state the following information: 
(1)  The starting or beginning time. 
(2)  The minimum speed, if applicable. 
(3)  The maximum speed, if applicable. 
(4)  The maximum interval of space to be maintained between the units of the parade or public assembly, if applicable. 
(5)  The portions of the streets to be traversed or utilized. 
(6)  The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof, if applicable. 
(7)  Such other information as the chief of police shall find necessary to the enforcement of this article. 
(Code 1977, § 19-77) 
Sec. 98-270. - Notice of rejection. 
    The chief of police shall act upon the application for a parade permit within five working days after the filing of such application. If the chief of police disapproves the application, he shall mail to the applicant, within five working days after the date upon which the application was filed, a notice of his action, stating the reasons for his denial of the permit. 
(Code 1977, § 19-73) 
Sec. 98-271. - Appeal procedure. 
    Any person aggrieved shall have the right to appeal the denial of a parade or public assembly permit to the board of commissioners. The appeal shall be taken within five working days after denial. The board of commissioners shall act upon the appeal at the next regularly scheduled commission meeting. 
(Code 1977, § 19-74) 
Sec. 98-272. - Alternative permit. 
    The chief of police, in denying an application for a parade or public assembly permit, shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of a parade or public assembly on a date, at a time or over a route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within seven days after notice of the action of the chief of police, file a written notice of acceptance with the chief of police. An alternate parade or public assembly permit shall conform to the requirements of and shall have the effect of a parade or public assembly permit under this article. 
(Code 1977, § 19-75) 
Sec. 98-273. - Notice by police chief to city and other officials. 
    Immediately upon the issuance of a parade or public assembly permit, the chief of police shall send a copy thereof to the following: 
(1)  The mayor. 
(2)  The chief operating officer. 
(3)  The city attorney. 
(4)  The fire chief. 
(5)  The city engineer. 
(6)  The board of commissioners. 
(7)  The city manager. 
(Code 1977, § 19-76) 
Sec. 98-274. - Duties of permittee. 
(a)  Compliance with laws. A permittee under this article shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. 
(b)  Possession of permit. The parade or public assembly chairman or other person heading or leading such activity shall carry the permit upon his person during the conduct of the parade or public assembly. 
(Code 1977, § 19-78) 
Sec. 98-275. - Revocation. 
    The chief of police shall have the authority to revoke a parade permit issued under this article upon application of the standards for issuance as set forth in this division. 
(Code 1977, § 19-80) 
Secs. 98-276-98-299. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - NEIGHBORHOOD TRAFFIC CALMING 

Sec. 98-300. - Purpose of article. 
    Vehicle speeding in residential neighborhoods is one of the most common traffic complaints reported to the traffic engineering services division and the city's police department. 
    Residents express their concerns about speeding in a number of ways which include: the danger to children playing outdoors, depressed property values, increased noise, and hazards to pedestrians and bicycle riders. However manifested, the concerns often lead to an effort to convince elected officials to take action to alleviate the problem with unwarranted traffic calming devices. 
    The purpose of this article is to present a criteria for reasonable and consistent evaluations as well as the applications of appropriate measures to control excessive speeding in residential areas. 
(Ord. No. 2007-48, § 1, 2-6-07; Ord. No. 2008-102, § 1, 4-22-08) 
Sec. 98-301. - Implementation. 
    The primary goal of implementing the proposed traffic calming measures is to reduce the impact of vehicles speeding in a residential neighborhood. In order to do this, the following procedure is recommended: 
(1)  Initiation: Speed studies for locations can be proposed by any of the following individuals: 
a.  Mayors office, city commissioners, and the city manager. 
b.  Public works department head and traffic engineering staff. 
c.  Dothan Police Department. 
d.  Citizen request. 
(2)  Data collection: Traffic engineering staff will conduct a speed study (85th percentile speed) and volume study, use existing traffic data, or make field observations for the requested street. The 85th percentile speed is the speed at, or below which 85 percent of the observed free flowing vehicles are traveling, and will be used as a measurement to determine if excessive speeding is occurring. 
(3)  Classification: The speed data will be analyzed to make sure that the data is correct and then will be classified into one of the following categories: 
a.  Class I (Minor): Measured 85th percentile speed is one to seven miles per hour above the posted speed limit. 
b.  Class II (Major): Measured 85th percentile speed is eight miles per hour or greater above the posted spped limit. 
(4)  Measures: Based on the classification of the vehicle speeds the following measures will be implemented: 
a.  Class I (Minor): Since the excessive speed is within the range of error of our equipment, a traffic calming petition will not be issued. 
b.  Class II (Major): If Class II speeding exists then the traffic engineering services division may consider the following traffic calming devices: 
1.  Multi-way stop: A sign stop at each approach of an intersection to slow down vehicles along the main street. It is the city's policy not to install multi-way stops at T-intersections. 
2.  Chokers: The installation of devices to narrow the lanes to slow vehicles down. 
3.  Speed humps: Raised areas, typically 2.5 inches by 22 feet by 12 feet, made of asphalt that are placed in a series at mid-block locations. 
4.  Traffic circles: Small islands in the center of an intersection. Edges are typically slope paved to accommodate larger vehicles and the center can be landscaped to be more aesthetically pleasing. 
(Ord. No. 2008-102, § 1, 4-22-08) 
Sec. 98-302. - Conditions for installing neighborhood traffic calming devices. 
(a)  Specifications. All traffic calming devices shall adhere to city specifications this includes, but not limited to speed humps, traffic circles, and chokers. 
(b)  Streets. Traffic calming devices will be considered for installation only on residential streets. The length of the street must be 1/4 mile or longer. 
(c)  Traffic volumes. Vehicle volumes must be at least 200 vehicles per day and not exceed 1,500 vehicles per day. Streets listed on the MPO Network Map or Supplement List in subsection (g) will not be considered for installation of traffic calming devices. These include all arterials and collectors (both major and minor) within the city. 
(d)  Speed. The speed limit for the requested location must be 25 or 30 miles per hour. 
(e)  Location of chokers and speed humps. Traffic engineering staff will determine the location and spacing of the speed humps or chokers. Factors such as lengths of the block, driveways, and storm drainage structures can affect the placement of these traffic calming measures. 
(f)  Traffic calming study. Once completed, there shall be a minimum of one year before another study will be conducted in the same area. 
(g)  Supplemental list of streets ineligible fro traffic calming. 
Adams Street Lingo Road Airport Drive Loftin Road Alice Street Lonsdale Drive Appletree Street Loraine Road Baggett Road Lucy Grade Road Barrington Road McCallister Road Bic Road Mimosa drive Blackman Toad Miskell Drive Bob Hall Road Moffet Road Briarcliff Road Moore Road Bruner Road Museum Avenue Burdeshaw Street (east and west) National Road Burkett Road Newton Street Carroll Street Oppert Road Catalpa Avenue Parramore Road Cherokee Avenue (north and south) Piney Road Grove Cherry Street Plum Road Chickasaw Street Powell Street Coe Dairy Road Race Track Road Crawford Street Redmond Road Dale County Road 25 Rollins Avenue Dale County Road 79 Rowland Road Drew Road Royal Parkway Dunn Road Sanitary Dairy Road Dusy Street Second Avenue Earline Road Selma Street (east and west) Edgewood Drive Shady Lane (north and south) Ennis Road Simms Road Fairview Avenue Smith Road Faulkner Street Southgate Road Festival Drive Speigner Street First Avenue Stadium Street Foster Street Starling Road Franklin Street Stephanie Lane Fuller Road Technology Drive Geiger Road Timbers Drive Green Valley Road Troy Street Grey Hodges Road Twitchell Road Haisten Drive Vulcan Way Hedstrom Drive Wallace Drive Hicks Road Washington Street Horace Shepard Road Wayne Road Hostdale Drive Wedgewood Drive Huskey Road W.G.
